242.01 COMPOSITION.
   (a)   The Police Department shall have a complement of not more than 15
officers, consisting of the Chief of the Department, Deputy Police Chief, three
Lieutenants (first line Supervisors), and not more than ten full-time patrol.
   (b)   The Police Department may also include such number of part-time police
officers as may be appointed by the Mayor at the request of the Police Chief
for good cause shown. All part-time police officers shall be required to
maintain in good standing a State license certificate. No part-time police
officer shall work more than 400 hours in any six- month period, unless, for
good cause shown by the Police Chief, the Mayor extends the number of hours
that a part-time police officer may work beyond the 400-hour limit.
   (c)   In the event that the number of members of the Police Department shall
hereafter be reduced, the reduction shall be made in the inverse order of
appointment and qualification of the different classes of members of the
Department.
   (d)   Northeast Ohio Regional Sewer District Safety and Security Auxiliary
Police Unit.
      (1)   Pursuant to R.C. § 737.161, an auxiliary police unit known as the
Northeast Ohio Regional Sewer District Safety and Security Auxiliary Police
Unit is hereby created. The Mayor may make appointments to said unit consistent
with R.C. § 737.161.
      (2)   Pursuant to R.C. § 737.16, and independent from the authority set
forth in R.C. § 737.161 and division (d)(1) of this section, the Mayor may,
subject to confirmation of Council, appoint police officers and special police
officers so that those officers may hold the commission requisite for the
officer to serve as a peace officer for the Northeast Ohio Regional Sewer
District.
      (3)   Nothing in this division (d) shall be construed as conferring or
infringing upon the rights or responsibilities of the members of the Police
Department described in division (a) of this section. Nor shall any individual
appointed pursuant to this division (d) enjoy any rights or benefits afforded
to members of any bargaining unit whose members work in the Police Department.
For the avoidance of doubt, the purpose of this division (d) is purely to
provide the Northeast Ohio Regional Sewer District’s law enforcement personnel
who have been certified by the State of Ohio as Peace Officers with the
commission requisite for those officers to continue to perform law enforcement
functions for the Northeast Ohio Regional Sewer District.
(Ord. 2000-130. Passed 10-25-00; Ord. 2004-20. Passed 1-14-04; Ord. 2006-174.
Passed 10-11-06; Ord. 2008-109. Passed 6-11-08; Ord. 2009-179. Passed 12-9-09;
Ord. 2010-32. Passed 3-10-10; Ord. 2014-24. Passed 2-12-14; Ord. 2014-50.
Passed 4-9-14; Ord. 2022-88. Passed 12-14-22; Ord. 2023-30. Passed 4-12-23.)
242.02 CLERK/DISPATCHERS. (REPEALED)
   (EDITOR’S NOTE: Section 242.02 was repealed by Ordinance 2022-88, passed
December 14, 2022.)
242.03 HOURS OF WORK.
   (a)   Except for emergency special duty assignments, the Shift Lieutenants,
police officers shall not work in excess of forty hours per week. Eight hours
per day constitutes a day's work. Subject to manpower and scheduling needs as
determined by the Police Chief, all these members shall work rotating shifts
including weekends, if it falls within their shift.
   (b)   The Police Chief and the Deputy Police Chief work at the discretion of
the Mayor, but shall work an average of 40 hours per week, generally Monday
through Friday.
   (c)   The Police Chief and the Deputy Police Chief shall be on call for duty
in the case of emergencies at all times.
   (d)   All members of the Police Department shall be required to log in and
out of work.
(Ord. 2022-88. Passed 12-14-22.)
242.04 ARREST NOTIFICATION BOOKS.
   The Chief of Police shall have custody of all books containing traffic
tickets and arrest notifications, and shall issue such books to the police
officers when needed. When all the tickets in each book have been issued, the
Chief shall file all used books. The third, yellow copy of all arrest
notifications shall be forwarded to the Clerk of Court who will send the yellow
copies to the Ohio Bureau of Motor Vehicles. The Chief shall keep a record of
all books issued and shall maintain custody of all books returned.
(Ord. 1993-72. Passed 5-26-93.)
242.05 CHARGES FOR USE OF POLICE CELLS.
   (a)   Any person permitted the use of the police cells in the Police
Department shall be chargeda reasonable rate per day or part thereof for each
use.
   (b)   The Mayor shall have authority to waive the foregoing charges under
such terms and conditions as are reasonable and proper.
(Ord. 1993-72. Passed 5-26-93; Ord. 2017-64. Passed 8-9-17.)
242.06 ESTABLISHMENT AND PURPOSE OF POLICE CONFIDENTIAL INVESTIGATION FUND.
   There is hereby established a fund, to be designated as the Police
Confidential Investigation Fund, in the amount of three thousand dollars
($3,000), for the use of the Police Department, to be appropriated in and
included as part of the annual appropriation for the General Fund to the Police
Department. The Police Chief, with the approval of the Mayor, may pay rewards
up to five hundred dollars ($500.00) each from the Fund to persons furnishing
information which leads to the arrest and conviction of persons committing any
misdemeanor set forth in
Chapter 624 of the General Offenses Code or violating any provision of Ohio
R.C. Chapter 3719 or committing any felony.
(Ord. 1993-72. Passed 5-26-93.)
242.07 CUSTODY OF POLICE CONFIDENTIAL INVESTIGATION FUND.
   The Chief of Police and any person authorized by him or her, in writing,
shall have sole custody of and jurisdiction over the Police Confidential
Investigation Fund, which Fund shall be used by the Police Department for
confidential investigation to determine whether the criminal laws of the
Village, State or Federal Government have been violated. No part of the Fund
shall be paid directly or indirectly to any person employed by the Village.
(Ord. 1993-72. Passed 5-26-93.)
242.08 ACCOUNTING FOR EXPENDITURES FROM POLICE CONFIDENTIAL INVESTIGATION FUND.
   The Chief of Police shall, when necessary to restore the amount of the
Police Confidential Investigation Fund, account for expenditures from the Fund
by delivery to the Chief Fiscal Officer of appropriate vouchers and receipts
evidencing each and every expenditure from such Fund, and on or before December
1 of every calendar year, he or she shall provide a written report to the Chief
Fiscal Officer, showing a complete and adequate reporting of the receipts and
expenditures of the Fund, together with a description of the purpose of the
expenditure. TheChief Fiscal Officer is hereby authorized and directed to
reimburse the Fund upon receipt of such properly executed vouchers and receipts
for investigation items, the cost of which cannot be recovered or reimbursed.
(Ord. 1993-72. Passed 5-26-93; Ord. 2017-64. Passed 8-9-17.)
242.09 LIABILITY INSURANCE.
   Upon terms available, the Village shall provide and pay for professional
liability insurance for members of the Police Department.
(Ord. 1993-72. Passed 5-26-93.)
242.10 ACCIDENT REPORTS.
   The Chief of Police shall charge a reasonable rate per page, consistent with
the Village’s Public Records Policy, for each accident report requested by any
person.
(Ord. 1997-144. Passed 11-12-97; Ord. 2012-97. Passed 11-14-12; Ord. 2017-64.
Passed 8-9-17.)
242.11 CHARGE FOR IMPOUNDING OF VEHICLES.
   Any person whose vehicle has been impounded on Village property by the
Police Department shall be charged ten dollars ($10.00) per day or part thereof
for such impoundment.
242.12 PETTY CASH FUND.
   There is hereby established a fund to be designated as the Police Department
Petty Cash Fund. Such Fund shall be in the amount of three hundred fifty
dollars ($350.00) and shall be for the use of the Police Department. Such Fund
shall be appropriated in and included as part of the General Fund to the
Department. The Chief of Police shall have custody of and jurisdiction over the
Fund and shall use the same for the purpose of making incidental purchases of
less than fifty dollars ($50.00).
(Ord. 1993-72. Passed 5-26-93; Ord. 2006-73. Passed 4-12-06.)
242.13 NONRESIDENT SERVICE.
   (a)   Pursuant to Ohio R.C. 737.041, as amended, the Chief of Police, the
Deputy Police Chief and the officers on duty in charge of the Police Department
are hereby authorized to render the services of the Police Department to other
municipalities, townships, counties or the State in times of emergency, whether
or not the Village has entered into mutual aid contracts for police services
with any of those political subdivisions or the State. The determination of
times of emergency shall be made only by the Chief of Police, the Deputy Police
Chief or the officers on duty in charge of the Police Department upon a call
for emergency police protection services by the State or by another political
subdivision of the State.
   (b)   The personnel of the Police Department rendering emergency services to
other political subdivisions shall, as provided by State law, be entitled to
all of their usual wages and benefits, shall be covered by workers'
compensation and shall be immune from any liability arising from the
reasonable, good faith rendering of emergency police protection services.
(Res. 1988-78. Passed 11-9-88; Ord. 2014-24. Passed 2-12-14; Ord. 2014-50.
Passed 4-9-14.)
242.14 TRAINING.
   All members of the Police Department shall be trained adequately and
appropriately. The Police Chief, in cooperation with all other members of the
Police Department, is hereby directed to draft and submit to Council a defined,
nondiscriminatory schooling and training policy to be approved by Council. This
policy shall be made part of the Rules and Regulations of the Police Department
and shall be reviewed at least every two years.
(Ord. 1996-67. Passed 4-24-96.)
242.15 PROCEDURES RE MISCONDUCT AND DISCIPLINE.
   An internal procedure for the submission of complaints relating to Police
Department misconduct and discipline shall be drafted by the Police Chief, in
cooperation with all other members of the Police Department, and submitted to
Council for approval. This procedure shall be made part of the Rules and
Regulations of the Police Department and shall be reviewed at least every two
years.
(Ord. 1996-67. Passed 4-24-96.)
242.16 ADMINISTRATIVE ASSISTANT TO THE CHIEF AND POLICE SERVICES.
   (a)   Position Established. There is hereby established a position to be
known as the Administrative Assistant to the Chief and Police Services.
(Ord. 1985-17. Passed 1-23-85.)
   (b)   Duties. The duties incident to the position of the Administrative
Assistant to the Chief and Police Services shall be to render secretarial and
clerical assistance to the Police Department and to perform such other and
additional duties and functions as the Mayor, the Police Chief, and the Deputy
Police Chief may from time to time require or designate. He or she shall work
eight hours per day, 40 hours per week.
(Ord. 1973-14. Passed 1-24-73.)
   (c)   Appointment and Term. The Administrative Assistant to the Chief and
Police Services shall be appointed and shall serve as prescribed in Section
230.01 .
   (d)   Uniform Allowances. The Administrative Assistant to the Chief and
Police Services, in addition to salaries and compensation provided, shall be
provided a uniform allowance as prescribed by Section
242.22 .
(Ord. 1990-105. Passed 10-10-90; Ord. 2006-50. Passed 3-8-06; Ord. 2014-24.
Passed 2-12-14; Ord. 2014-50. Passed 4-9-14; Ord. 2017-83. Passed 12-13-17.)
242.17 POLICE OFFICERS ON SPECIAL DUTY.
   When request is made for special services of police officers by private
persons or social or business organizations within the Village, the Mayor may
allow such services to be performed if such personnel are available and if such
services do not interfere with the regular public duties of such personnel. The
personnel rendering the services requested shall be paid directly by the
persons or organizations who receive such services on such terms as may be
agreed upon. Such payments shall not be regarded as salary or entered upon the
Village payroll.
(Ord. 1993-37. Passed 3-10-93.)
242.18 SPECIAL A.I.D.S. COMPENSATION.
   When a member of the Police Department has been diagnosed as having
contracted Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome in the course of his or her
duties, the Village shall compensate the employee the difference between his or
her disability pension and the base salary the employee would have earned until
the employee's date of death.
(Ord. 1993-37. Passed 3-10-93.)
242.19 SHOW-UP TIME FOR SERVICE ON OFF-DUTY HOURS.
   When a full-time member of the Police Department is called back to duty
during his or her normal off-duty hours, such member shall be entitled to show-
up time of a minimum of two hours (four hours if recalled after the third or
"midnight" shift). Show-up time shall be paid at the employee's regular rate of
compensation plus overtime if such is due and payable.
(Ord. 1994-65. Passed 4-27-94.)
242.20 SHIFT INCENTIVE COMPENSATION.
   All full-time hourly members of the Police Department, including the Clerk/
Dispatchers, who work shifts, shall receive an additional amount of
compensation, payable for the pay period earned of fifty cents($0.50)  per hour
for the second shift and one dollar ($1.00) per hour for the third shift. The
part-time Clerk/Dispatcher's compensation shall be pro-rated, based on a
thirty-two hour work week.
(Ord. 2000-31. Passed 4-12-00.)
242.21 ACTING LIEUTENANT'S PAY.
   Police officers shall be paid at the rate of pay for Lieutenant for time
served in the capacity of Lieutenant when such service is not less than eight
hours. Acting Lieutenant's pay shall only be given for time actually worked.
(Ord. 1993-37. Passed 3-10-93.)
242.22 UNIFORM ALLOWANCES.
   (a)   In addition to the salaries and compensation provided for the members
of the Police Department, the Village shall furnish the cost of all dress
uniforms required by members of the Department. Any uniforms ruined or
destroyed in the line of duty within one year from the date of purchase shall
be replaced by the Village with the approval of the Police Chief. The Chief,
subject to the approval of the Mayor, shall designate the design and style of
the uniforms for the Department.
   (b)   Allowable items may be purchased by the member with approval from the
Police Chief. The member may purchase an item he or she deems necessary, at
intervals designated by the Police Chief, not to exceed the amount established
in the policy set forth by the Chief per calendar year.
      Full-Time Officers:
      All full-time members of the Police Department below the rank of Deputy
Chief will be subject to the most current collective bargaining article
concerning uniform allowance and to the Cuyahoga Heights Police Department’s
Uniform Policy.
      Part-Time Officers:
      All part-time officers will receive a uniform allowance according to the
Cuyahoga Police Department’s Policy regarding part-time uniform allowance as
established by the Chief. Not to exceed six hundred dollars ($600) per officer
in one calendar year.
      Non-Bargaining Unit Members:
      All full-time non-bargaining unit members will receive a uniform
allowance according to the Cuyahoga Heights Police Department’s Policy
regarding non-bargaining unit employee’s uniform allowances. Not to exceed one
thousand dollars ($1,000) per employee in one calendar year.
   (c)   The written approval of the Police Chief shall precede any purchases.
All purchases will only be made through suppliers approved by the Chief.
(Ord. 1993-37. Passed 3-10-93.)
   (d)   The following non-bargaining employees of the Police Department shall
receive an annual clothing maintenance allowance as follows: Police Chief, six
hundred dollars ($600.00); Deputy Police Chief, six hundred dollars ($600.00).
Said allowance shall be paid annually in December of each year. If employment
qualifying for the clothing maintenance allowance terminates prior to December
of the applicable year, the allowance shall be prorated.
   (e)   The Police Chief, Deputy Chief, and any part-time officers whose
primary appointing agency is the Cuyahoga Heights Police Department will be
entitled to one approved ballistic vest every five years.
(Ord. 2000-73. Passed 5-10-00; Ord. 2005-79. Passed 5-11-05; Ord. 2006-51.
Passed 3-8-06; Ord. 2006-100. Passed 6-7-06; Ord. 2008-112. Passed 6-11-08;
Ord. 2009-179. Passed 12-9-09; Ord. 2010-32. Passed 3-10-10; Ord. 2014-10.
Passed 1-8-14; Ord. 2014-24. Passed 2-12-14; Ord. 2014-50. Passed 4-9-14; Ord.
2018-13. Passed 1-10-18.)
242.23 PHYSICAL EXAMINATIONS REQUIRED.
   The Mayor shall require all members of the Police Department to be examined
by an outside medical officer of his or her choice at intervals of no less than
two years.
(Ord. 1997-68. Passed 5-14-97.)
242.24 IMMUNIZATION PROGRAM.
   (a)   The Police Chief is hereby authorized and directed to create and
implement an immunization program for all members of the Police Department. The
Police Chief shall consult with the Mayor and Village Law Director in creating
and implementing the immunization program. The program shall contain a
provision that if a member of the Police Department refuses to take the
prescribed immunization shots, such member shall be required to sign a release
form relieving the Village of any liability.
   (b)   The Chief Fiscal Officer is hereby authorized and directed to
appropriate the necessary funds and pay the necessary expenses required to have
all members of the Police Department receive immunization shots.
(Ord. 2017-64. Passed 8-9-17.)
242.25 JUVENILE DIVERSION PROGRAM FUND.
   (a)   There is hereby created a fund to be known as the Juvenile Diversion
Program Fund, a special revenue fund, for use by the Chief of Police and the
Juvenile Diversion Officer, to operate the Village Diversion Program, to be
appropriated in and included as part of the annual appropriations for Special
Revenue Funds.
   (b)   The Chief of Police and any person authorized by him or her, in
writing, shall have sole custody of and jurisdiction over the Juvenile
Diversion Program Fund.
   (c)   The Chief of Police and any person authorized by him or her shall
account for expenditures from the Fund by delivering to the Clerk a complete
and adequate written report of the receipts ands expenditures of the Fund,
together with a description of the purpose of the expenditure.
(Ord. 2002-150. Passed 11-13-02; Ord. 2017-64. Passed 8-9-17.)
242.26 POLICE OFFICER ATTENDANCE AT SPECIAL EVENTS AT COMMERCIAL FACILITIES.
   Any person operating a commercial facility attended by more than 100 person
at which alcohol is served shall be required to contract with the Police
Department and pay for a uniformed police officer to provide security at such
event. The Mayor, in conjunction with the Chief of Police be and hereby is
authorized and directed to provide rules to implement this section.
(Ord. 2004-96. Passed 6-9-04.)
242.27 PART-TIME JAILERS.
   (a)   Position Established. There is hereby established a position to be
known as Non-Regular Police Jailer. Individuals holding this position must
comply with the Rules and Regulations promulgated by the Village Police
Department, as amended from time to time.
   (b)   Duties. The duties incident to the position of the Jailer shall be
maintaining the security and safety of the prisoners incarcerated in the Police
Department Jail and to perform such other and additional duties and functions
as directed by the Police Chief and/or Jail Administrator. Applicants for the
position of Non-Regular Police Jailer shall be at least 21 years of age. The
Mayor, with the approval of Council, may refuse to consider an applicant for
the position of Non-Regular Police Jailer who is a current user of illegal
drugs; who has been convicted of a felony; who has been guilty of infamous or
notoriously disgraceful conduct; who has been dismissed from any public
position for delinquency or misconduct; or who has made false statements of any
material fact or practice or attempted to practice any deception or fraud in
his or her application or in his or her examination in establishing his or her
ability or securing his or her appointment.
   (c)   Appointment and Term. The part-time Non-Regular Police Jailers shall
be appointed by the Mayor, as the need arises, with a recommendation from the
Police Chief and/or Jail Administrator.
   (d)   Uniform Allowances. The Part-time Jailers, in addition to salaries and
compensation provided, shall be provided a uniform allowance as prescribed by
this section.
(Ord. 2007-85. Passed 7-11-07; Ord. 2007-137. Passed 8-8-07; Ord. 2008-25.
Passed 2-13-08; Ord. 2014-19. Passed 2-12-14; Ord. 2017-64. Passed 8-9-17.)
242.28 CONTINUING PROFESSIONAL TRAINING (CPT) FUND.
   (a)   There is hereby created a fund to be know as the Continuing
Professional Training (CPT) Fund, a special revenue fund, for the use of the
Chief of Police and any person authorized by him or her, to comply with Senate
Bill 281 by providing continuing professional training for the officers in the
Police Department, to be appropriated in and included as part of the annual
appropriations for Special Revenue Funds.
   (b)   The Chief of Police and any person authorized by him or her, in
writing, shall have sole custody of and jurisdiction over the Continuing
Professional Training (CPT) Fund, including but not limited to training
qualifications, record keeping, reporting, and enforcement, etc.
   (c)   The Chief of Police and any person authorized by him or her shall
account for expenditures from the Fund by delivery to the Chief Fiscal Officer
a complete and adequate written report of the grants requests, receipts and
expenditures of the Fund, together with a description of the purpose of the
expenditure.
(Ord. 2008-24. Passed 2-13-08; Ord. 2017-64. Passed 8-9-17.)
CHAPTER 244
Fire Department
EDITOR'S NOTE: Rules and Regulations for the Fire Department were adopted by

from the Fire Chief.

   Ordinance 2010-127, passed January 12, 2011, abolishes the positions of
Captain in the Fire Department. The current positions of Fire Captain are
abolished effective simultaneously with each incumbent in the current Fire
Captain positions leaving the position of Captain for any reason.

   Driving over fire hose - see TRAF.

660.08
244.01 COMPOSITION.
   (a)   The Fire Department shall consist of a Chief of the Department, an
Assistant Chief who shall perform the functions of the Municipal Fire Safety
Inspector, subject to Section
1610.04 and not more than 12 firefighters. Upon the resignation, retirement or
removal of the Fire Chief, the Assistant Fire Chief shall be named as the Fire
Chief. Not more than three of the firefighters may be designated as Lieutenant
by the Mayor, subject to the approval of Council and subject to the provisions
of
Chapter 246. Upon passage of this section, one firefighter will be designated
as Captain by the Mayor, subject to the approval of Council, and subject to the
provisions of
Chapter 246. That Captain, and any other firefighters designated as Captain
upon passage of this section will remain in said position, until resignation,
retirement or removal. No other firefighter shall be designated as Captain
thereafter.
   (b)   The Fire Department may also include such number of part-time
firefighters as may be appointed by the Mayor at the request of the Fire Chief
for good cause shown. All part-time firefighters shall be required to maintain
in good standing with all state licensing. No part-time firefighter shall work
more than 400 hours in any six-month period, unless, for good cause shown by
the Fire Chief, the Mayor, with the approval of Council, extends the number of
hours that a part-time firefighter may work beyond the 400-hour limit.
(Ord. 1997-38. Passed 3-26-97; Ord. 2001-36. Passed 4-11-01; Ord. 2002-169.
Passed 12-11-02; Ord. 2008-110. Passed 6-11-08; Ord. 2009-178. Passed 12-9-09;
Ord. 2010-30. Passed 3-10-10; Ord. 2010-59. Passed 6-9-10; Ord. 2011-56. Passed
8-10-11.)
244.02 HOURS OF WORK.
   (a)   The Fire Chief and Assistant Fire Chief shall work at the discretion
of the Mayor, an average of forty hours per week, generally Monday through
Friday. All other full-time fire-fighters shall be on active duty in the
performance of their duties in shifts of not less than 24 hours on and 48 hours
off. Members of the Fire Department shall work six tours of duty (144 hours) in
each 21-day work period. All members of the Fire Department shall be on call in
the event of an emergency.
   (b)   The foregoing hours of work may be changed by the Fire Chief to a 40-
hour work week for the full tour of Fire Cadets when attending the required
Fire Cadet Training Program and may further be changed to accommodate a member
who is attending school or training sessions other than the Cadet Training
Program when such attendance is required by the Village and may further be
changed to allow the transfer of members from one shift to another, provided it
does not conflict with State or Federal Law.
(Ord. 1993-36. Passed 3-10-93; Ord. 2010-59. Passed 6-9-10; Ord. 2013-18.
Passed 2-13-13.)
244.03 NONRESIDENT SERVICE.
   (a)   Pursuant to Ohio R.C. 9.60, as amended, the Fire Chief and the
officers on duty in charge of the Fire Department are hereby authorized to
render the services of the Fire Department to other municipalities, townships,
counties or the State in times of emergency, whether or not the Village has
entered into mutual aid contracts for fire services with any of those political
subdivisions or the State. The determination of times of emergency shall be
made only by the Fire Chief or the officers on duty in charge of the Fire
Department upon a call for emergency fire protection services by the State or
another political subdivision of the State.
   (b)   The personnel of the Fire Department rendering emergency services to
other political subdivisions shall, as provided by State law, be entitled to
all of their usual wages and benefits, shall be covered by workers'
compensation and shall be immune from any liability arising from the
reasonable, good faith rendering of emergency fire protection services.
(Res. 1988-78. Passed 11-9-88.)
244.04 LIABILITY INSURANCE.
   Upon terms available, the Village shall provide and pay for professional
liability insurance for members of the Fire Department.
(Ord. 1993-36. Passed 3-10-93.)
244.05 PARAMEDIC COMMITTEE.
   There is hereby established a committee to be know as the Paramedic
Committee, consisting of the Mayor, the Fire Chief and three members of the
Fire Department with current paramedic status. The Paramedic Committee shall
meet from time to time and shall review the number of paramedics and the
training and certification of paramedics and shall be authorized to make
recommendations to the Fire Chief and Council to insure that there is an
adequate complement of trained and certified paramedics in the Fire Department
at all times to serve and protect the citizens of the Village.
(Ord. 1993-36. Passed 3-10-93.)
244.06 PARAMEDIC COMPENSATION IN THE FIRE DEPARTMENT.
   (a)   Members of the Fire Department, excluding the Fire Chief and Assistant
Fire Chief, who have possessed, during the entire calendar year, a current,
valid Certificate of Competency in Emergency Medical Technician-Paramedic
pursuant to Ohio R.C. 4765.30 and 4765.39, as amended, shall be paid an
additional fixed amount of compensation, payable in the final pay period of the
year, as established by Council.
   (b)   Subject to Section
246.10, if a full-time member of the Fire Department is allowed by the Fire
Chief to relinquish his or her paramedic status during the year, the individual
shall be paid a pro rata portion of the additional fixed amount of
compensation, as established by Council, for that portion of the year during
which the individual retained his or her paramedic status.
   (c)   Members of the Fire Department, excluding the Fire Chief and Assistant
Fire Chief, who have maintained a current, valid Emergency Medical Technician-
Ambulance Certificate, or Advanced Emergency Medical Technician-Ambulance
Certificate, during the calendar year, pursuant to Ohio R.C. 4765.30, 4765.37
and 4765.38, as amended, who are not entitled to receive extra compensation for
holding a Paramedic Certificate, shall receive an additional fixed amount of
compensation, payable in the final pay period of each year, as established by
Council.
(Ord. 1998-48. Passed 3-11-98; Ord. 2010-30. Passed 3-10-10; Ord. 2013-18.
Passed 2-13-13.)
244.07 SPECIAL A.I.D.S. COMPENSATION.
   When a member of the Fire Department has been diagnosed as having contracted
Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome in the course of his or her duties, the
Village shall compensate the employee the difference between his or her
disability pension and the base salary the employee would have earned until the
employee's date of death.
(Ord. 1993-37. Passed 3-10-93.)
244.08 SHOW-UP TIME FOR SERVICE ON OFF-DUTY HOURS.
   When a full-time member of the Fire Department is called back to duty during
his or her normal off-duty hours, such member shall be entitled to show-up time
of a minimum of two hours (four hours if recalled after midnight, but before 7:
30 a.m.). Show-up time shall be paid at the employee's regular rate of
compensation plus overtime if such is due and payable.
(Ord. 2000-29. Passed 4-12-00.)
244.09 FIRE-FIGHTERS ON SPECIAL DUTY.
   When request is made for special services on fire-fighters by private
persons or social or business organizations within the Village, the Mayor may
allow such services to be performed if such personnel are available and if such
services do not interfere with the regular public duties of such personnel. The
personnel rendering the services requested shall be paid directly by the
persons or organizations who receive such services on such terms as may be
agreed upon. Such payments shall not be regarded as salary or entered upon the
Village payroll.
(Ord. 1993-37. Passed 3-10-93.)
244.10 ACTING LIEUTENANT'S PAY.
   Fire-fighters shall be paid at the rate of pay for Lieutenant for time
served in the capacity of Lieutenant when such service is not less than one
tour of duty for fire-fighters. Acting Lieutenant's pay shall only be given for
time actually worked.
(Ord. 1993-37. Passed 3-10-93.)
244.11 UNIFORM ALLOWANCES.
   (a)   In addition to the salaries and compensation provided for the members
of the Fire Department, the Village shall furnish the cost of all dress
uniforms required by members of the Fire Department. Any uniform ruined or
destroyed in the line of duty within one year from the date of purchase shall
be replaced by the Village with the approval of the Fire Chief. The Fire Chief,
subject to the approval of the Mayor, shall designate the design and style of
the uniforms for the Fire Department.
   (b)   Dress uniforms in the Fire Department may be replaced after no less
than five years of normal use at Village cost, subject to approval of the Fire
Chief.
   (c)   Allowable items may be purchased by a member with the approval from
the Fire Chief. The member may purchase an item he or she deems necessary, at
intervals designated by the Fire Chief, not to exceed the amount established in
the policy set forth by the Chief per calendar year. The allowable items in the
Fire Department are as follows:
      Firefighters:
      4 work shirts
      4 summer shirts
      4 summer T-shirts
      4 pairs of pants
      4 (packages) socks (black)
      2 crew-neck sweatshirts
      1 insulated winter hooded sweatshirt
      1 Blauer jacket (approved style)
      1 pair of winter gloves
      1 turtleneck shirt
      1 pair of shoes (approved style)
      1 belt
      1 knit cap
      1 pair of sweat pants and/or shorts
      1 Department gear bag (every 3 years)
      1 squad jacket (every 3 years)
      1 pair of squad boots (every 3 years)
      1 top coat (every 5 years)
   (d)   The written approval of the Fire Chief shall precede any purchases. No
allowance shall be made for purchases unless such items are needed.
   (e)   The Fire Chief and Assistant Fire Chief shall be permitted a uniform
allowance in lieu of the foregoing which shall be subject to the approval of
the Mayor. Instances where such costs exceed nine hundred dollars ($900.00)
shall be subject to the prior approval of Council.
   (f)   The Fire Chief, Assistant Fire Chief, and full-time firefighters shall
receive an annual clothing maintenance allowance of six hundred dollars
($600.00) per year, payable annually in December of each year, unless otherwise
set forth in an applicable collective bargaining agreement. If employment
qualifying for said clothing maintenance allowance terminates prior to December
of the applicable year, the allowance shall be prorated.
(Ord. 2000-73. Passed 5-10-00; Ord. 2006-100. Passed 6-7-06; Ord. 2010-30.
Passed 3-10-10; Ord. 2010-59. Passed 6-9-10; Ord. 2013-18. Passed 2-13-13; Ord.
2014-11. Passed 1-8-14.)
244.12 IMMUNIZATION PROGRAM.
   (a)   The Fire Chief is hereby authorized and directed to create and
implement an immunization program for all members of the Fire Department. The
Fire Chief shall consult with the Mayor and Village Solicitor in creating and
implementing the immunization program. The program shall contain a provision
that if a member of the Fire Department refuses to take the prescribed
immunization shots, such member shall be required to sign a release form
relieving the Village of any liability.
   (b)   The Clerk and Treasurer are hereby authorized and directed to
appropriate the necessary funds and pay the necessary expenses required to have
all members of the Fire Department receive immunization shots.
(Res. 1986-76. Passed 9-24-86.)
244.13 UNDERGROUND STORAGE TANKS.
   (a)   The Fire Department is hereby authorized and directed to inspect and
issue written permits for the installation of, the making of major repairs on-
site to, the abandonment of, and the removal of, underground storage tanks, as
that term is defined in Chapter 2 of the Ohio Fire Code, as adopted in
Chapter 1610 of the Fire Prevention Code, within the Village Fire Department's
jurisdictional area.
   (b)   The Fire Chief, being the Fire Department's UST Inspection
Coordinator, or his or her designee, is hereby authorized and directed to
forward a certified copy of this section to the Ohio Department of Commerce,
Division of State Fire Marshal, Bureau of Underground Storage Tank Regulations.
(Ord. 1991-22. Passed 2-13-91; Ord. 2010-30. Passed 3-10-10.)
244.14 PHYSICAL EXAMINATIONS REQUIRED.
   The Mayor shall require all members of the Fire Department to be examined by
an outside medical officer of his or her choice at intervals of no less than
two years.
(Ord. 1997-68. Passed 5-14-97.)
244.15 PETTY CASH FUND.
   There is hereby created a fund to be designated as the Fire Department Petty
Cash Fund. Such fund shall be in the amount of two hundred fifty dollars
($250.00) and shall be for the use of the Fire Department. Such fund shall be
appropriated in and included as part of the annual appropriation of the General
Fund to the Department. The Fire Chief shall have custody of and jurisdiction
over the fund and he or she shall use the same for the purpose of making
incidental purchases of less than fifty dollars ($50.00).
(Ord. 2003-53. Passed 4-9-03.)
244.16 USER FEE FOR EMERGENCY MEDICAL SERVICES.
   (a)   The following user fees are hereby approved, adopted and levied and
shall be paid by those individuals and/or organizations making use of the

CHAPTER 246
Police and Fire Appointments and Promotions
246.01   Purpose.
246.02   Compliance required.
246.03   Eligibility lists, generally.
246.04   Applications.
246.05   Timing of examinations.
246.06   Initial appointment examinations and qualifications.
246.07   Promotional examination and qualifications.
246.08   Review committee and creation of eligibility list.
246.09   Credits.
246.10   Appointments from the eligibility list.
246.11   Probationary periods.
246.12   EMT and paramedic requirements in the Fire Department.
246.13   Ohio Peace Officer training certificate requirements in the Police
Department.
246.14   Full-time Police Dispatcher requirements.
246.15   Part-time Police Dispatcher requirements.
246.16   Lateral transfers.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Council to provide for appointment and promotion of police officers and
fire-fighters - see CHTR.
Art. V, § 4
   Appointments under civil service law - see Ohio R.C. 124.27, 124.41, 124.42,
124.49
   Promotions - see Ohio R.C. 124.44, 124.45
   Composition of Police Department - see ADM.
242.01
   Composition of Fire Department - see ADM.
244.01
246.01 PURPOSE.
   This chapter is adopted pursuant to
Article V, Section 4, of the Village Charter, which requires that Council
provide by ordinance for competitive examinations to ascertain the merit and
fitness of applicants for appointment to and promotion within the Fire
Department and Police Department and permits Council to establish age,
residency, and other requirements for such appointments and promotions.
(Ord. 2012-32. Passed 5-9-12.)
246.02 COMPLIANCE REQUIRED.
   No person shall be appointed as a full-time employee or promoted in the
Police or Fire Department of the Village in any manner or by any means other
than those prescribed in this chapter.
(Ord. 2012-32. Passed 5-9-12.)
246.03 ELIGIBILITY LISTS, GENERALLY.
   (a)   The Village shall create a list of persons eligible for new hire
positions within the Fire and Police Departments when the Village determines a
need for an original appointment eligibility list. A list of persons eligible
for promotions within the Fire and Police Departments may be created when there
is a vacancy or a vacancy appears imminent in any rank that is to be filled by
promotion, except for the positions of Police Chief and Fire Chief. Eligibility
lists shall be created through the application, examination, ranking, and
selection process set forth in this
Chapter 246.
   (b)   Eligibility lists shall be effective only for the department for which
the list was originally created. The eligibility list shall become effective
upon posting of the list by the Village Administration, pursuant to Section
246.08, and shall remain in effect for a period of one year or until a new
eligibility list is posted, whichever occurs earlier. Council may extend the
effective date of any eligibly list through legislative action.
(Ord. 2012-32. Passed 5-9-12; Ord. 2017-98. Passed 12-13-17; Ord. 2019-81.
Passed 10-9-19.)
246.04 APPLICATIONS.
   (a)   Each applicant seeking an initial appointment or a promotion in either
the Fire or Police Departments shall file with the Mayor, by the deadline set
by the Mayor, or if no deadline is set, then within a reasonable time prior to
the proposed examination, a formal application in which the applicant shall
state under oath or affirmation as follows:
      (1)   His or her full name, residence and post office address;
      (2)   His or her age, place and date of birth;
      (3)   His or her business employment and residence for the previous five
years;
      (4)   Such other information as may reasonably be required pertaining to
the applicant's fitness for the position sought; and
      (5)   Applicants for initial appointment in the Police Department shall
provide a copy of the Ohio Peace Officer Training Council Certificate, if the
applicant has such a certificate. The certificate is not required for
application or appointment.
      (6)   Applicants for initial appointment in the Fire or Police
Departments who wish to receive credits for honorable discharge from service in
the uniformed services, pursuant to Section
246.09 of this chapter shall provide a copy of the DD-214 Form, or other proof
of such service.
      (7)   Applicants for initial appointment in the Fire Department must
submit proof of successful completion of the State of Ohio Firefighter Level 2
Certification Course.
      (8)   Applicants for initial appointment in the Fire Department must
submit proof that the applicant is certified as a paramedic by the State of
Ohio.
   (b)   Blank forms for an application shall be furnished by the Mayor to any
person eligible to take the examination. All applications shall be filled with
the Mayor in duplicate and one copy, receipted by the Mayor, shall be returned
to the applicant.
(Ord. 2012-32. Passed 5-9-12; Ord. 2016-46. Passed 6-8-16.)
246.05 TIMING OF EXAMINATIONS.
   Reasonable notice of the time, place and general scope of the examination
shall be given by the Village. Such notices shall also be posted by the Mayor
in a conspicuous place in the Village Hall and in the Police and Fire
Departments, as applicable, at least two weeks prior to the examination.
   (a)   Timing of Examinations for Initial Appointment. Competitive
examinations for initial appointment in the Police and Fire Departments shall
be administered by the Village as follows:
      (1)   For initial appointments within the Police Department, the
professional competency examination will be conducted on an as-needed basis, as
determined by the Mayor in consultation with the Chief of Police. Physical
ability examinations shall be held within three months of the date of the
professional competency examination. Additional examinations may be
administered if a vacancy cannot be filled by the standing list of eligible
persons or if the standing list of eligible persons contains less than two
names.
      (2)   For initial appointments within the Fire Department, the
professional competency examination will be conducted by an appropriate testing
entity designated by the Village, according to parameters established by the
Village. Additional examinations may be administered if a vacancy cannot be
filled by the existing list of eligible persons or if the existing list of
eligible persons contains less than two names.
   (b)   Timing of Promotional Examinations. Competitive examinations shall be
administered pursuant to Section
246.07  when there is a vacancy or a vacancy appears imminent in any rank that
is to be filled by promotion in the Police Department. Unless otherwise set
forth in this chapter, if there is only one applicant for a promotion in the
Police Department, the professional competency examination shall be dispensed
with and the applicant shall be appointed to the position to be filled, if
otherwise qualified, subject to Section
246.07 (c). If the applicant is deemed not qualified, the Mayor shall take
necessary action to fill the position.
(Ord. 2012-32. Passed 5-9-12; Ord. 2017-98. Passed 12-13-17; Ord. 2018-87.
Passed 11-14-18; Ord. 2019-81. Passed 10-9-19.)
246.06 INITIAL APPOINTMENT EXAMINATIONS AND QUALIFICATIONS.
   (a)   Initial Appointment Examinations. Applicants for initial appointment
to the Police or Fire Department shall be subject to the following
examinations:
      (1)   Physical ability.
         A.   An outside person or agency, commissioned by the Mayor, shall
conduct an examination which fairly tests the ability of the person examined to
physically perform the duties of the position for which the appointment is
made. This examination may consist of battery of physical tasks. For police
officers, the examination shall be substantially similar to the Ohio Peace
Officer Training Program (OPOTA) basic training physical fitness test. For
firefighters, the examination shall be substantially similar to the Cuyahoga
Community College Fire Training Academy's task-oriented physical agility test
with a four and a half-minute completion time. This examination shall be a
pass/fail exam; no grade shall be given. If an applicant does not obtain a
passing grade on the physical ability examination, the applicant shall be
disqualified from eligibility.
         B.   The physical ability examination requirement may be deemed
satisfied if the applicant produces a certification of passage of a physical
ability test substantially similar to the applicable physical ability
examination set forth in Section
246.06(a)(1)A. conducted by a qualified and reputable institution, which test
must have been given within one year prior to the date of the Village's
scheduled physical ability examination. The Mayor shall have sole discretion to
determine whether the provisions of this Section
246.06(a)(1)B. have been met.
      (2)   Professional competency. The Mayor shall select an outside agency
to conduct a professional competency examination for all eligible applicants
for the position to be filled. Such examination may be written or written and
oral, but in all cases all parts of the test shall be combined into one grade.
The examination shall be practical in character and shall relate directly to
those matters which fairly test the capacity of the person examined to
discharge the particular duties of the position for which the appointment is to
be made, with a particular focus on knowledge unique to or particularly
relevant to serving in the Village.
      (3)   Psychological and physical health. After a conditional offer of
initial appointment in the Fire or Police Department, the Mayor shall select an
outside medical officer to conduct an examination which fairly tests
psychological and physical health of the applicant to ensure the applicant's
ability to perform the duties of the position. The medical officer shall
establish the psychological and physical health standards for qualification and
shall be the sole judge as to whether an applicant meets these standards.
   (b)   Qualifications for Initial Appointment.
      (1)   The Mayor, with the approval of Council, may refuse to allow an
applicant to be examined, or after an examination may refuse to consider an
applicant for the position who is found to lack any of the established
preliminary requirements for the examination; who is unable to perform the
essential functions of the position with or without a reasonable accommodation;
who is a current user of illegal drugs; who has been convicted of a felony; who
has been guilty of infamous or notoriously disgraceful conduct; who has been
dismissed from any public position for delinquency or misconduct; or who has
made false statements of any material fact or practiced or attempted to
practice any deception or fraud in his or her application or in his or her
examination in establishing his or her eligibility or securing his or her
appointment.
      (2)   Any member receiving an initial appointment as a member of the Fire
or Police Department shall be a citizen of the United States and, if a
naturalized citizen, shall submit his or her Naturalization Certificate.
      (3)   No person shall be eligible to take an examination for original
appointment as a firefighter or a police officer unless the person is a high
school graduate or has an Ohio GED equivalent.
      (4)   No person shall be eligible to take an examination for original
appointment as a firefighter unless the person is at least 18 years of age and
no more than 35 years of age at the time of the professional competency
examination for the applicable department, 37 years of age in the case of the
Fire Department. No person shall be eligible to take an examination for
original appointment as a police officer unless the person is at least 21 years
of age at the time the person is appointed and no more than 35 years of age at
the time of the competitive examination for the applicable department. If a
person is no more than 35 years of age, or 37 years of age in the case of the
Fire Department, when he or she takes the professional competency examination,
he or she may remain qualified for his or her appointment until the expiration
of the eligibility list created from said examination, provided he or she
remains qualified pursuant to the other requirements of these Codified
Ordinances.
(Ord. 2012-32. Passed 5-9-12; Ord. 2018-90. Passed 10-10-18; Ord. 2019-81.
Passed 10-9-19.)
246.07 PROMOTIONAL EXAMINATION AND QUALIFICATIONS.
   (a)   Promotional Examination. Applicants for promotion in the Police
Department shall be subject to a professional competency examination, which may
include a written examination and interviews. After a conditional offer of
promotion to fill a vacancy in the Fire or Police Department, the Mayor may
select an outside medical officer to conduct an examination which fairly tests
the ability of the person examined to psychologically perform the duties of the
position for which the appointment is made. The psychological examination shall
only be required for promotions upon the recommendation of the Mayor.
   (b)   Qualifications for Promotions.
      (1)   Fire Chief. In the case of a vacancy in the position of Fire Chief,
the Assistant Fire Chief shall be promoted to the position of Fire Chief. If
the Assistant Fire Chief refuses the position, the Mayor may hire a Fire Chief
at his or her own discretion from within or outside of the Fire Department.
      (2)   Assistant Fire Chief. In the case of a vacancy in the position of
Assistant Fire Chief, the Captains and the Lieutenants in the Fire Department
shall be eligible to take the competitive examination and be eligible for
promotion to the position. The position of Assistant Fire Chief shall be
awarded to the applicant who obtains the highest rank on the eligibility list
created pursuant to Section 246.08. One year of service in grade is required
for eligibility to be an applicant.
      (3)   Lieutenant in the Fire Department. In the case of a vacancy in the
position of Lieutenant in the Fire Department, only the firefighters shall be
eligible to take the examination and be eligible for promotion to the position.
The position shall be filed by the applicant who obtains the highest score on
the eligibility list. Five years of service in grade are required for
eligibility to be an applicant.
      (4)   Police Chief. In the case of a vacancy in the position of Police
Chief, the Mayor may fill the position by appointment in his sole discretion.
      (5)   Deputy Police Chief. In the case of a vacancy in the position of
Deputy Police Chief, the Mayor may fill the position by appointment in his sole
discretion.
      (6)   Lieutenant in the Police Department. In the case of a vacancy in
the position of Lieutenant in the Police Department, only patrol officers shall
be eligible for promotion to the position of Lieutenant. Five years of service
in grade are required for eligibility to be an applicant. The Mayor may select
the Lieutenant in the Police Department from among the three highest scored
candidates on the promotional eligibility list. If a candidate is passed over
for promotion twice, that candidate shall be removed from the promotional
eligibility list. When a candidate is either selected from the promotional
eligibility list or a candidate is removed from the promotional eligibility
list because of being passed over twice, the subsequent eligible candidates on
the promotional eligibility list shall move up in placing.
   (c)   Mayoral Discretion. Notwithstanding the provisions of Section
246.07 (b), if the Mayor determines, in his or her sole discretion, that the
candidate set to fill the vacancy, pursuant to the above provisions in this
Section
246.07 , is unfit for the position, the Mayor may opt to decline not to appoint
that candidate. If the Mayor determines, in his or her sole discretion, that
all candidates on the eligibility list are unfit for the position, the Mayor
may hire any other person from within the applicable department or from outside
of the department to fill the vacancy.
(Ord. 2012-32. Passed 5-9-12; Ord. 2014-27. Passed 2-12-14; Ord. 2017-98.
Passed 12-13-17.)
246.08 REVIEW COMMITTEE AND CREATION OF ELIGIBILITY LIST.
   (a)   A three-person Review Committee shall be created for each Police
Department entrance and promotional examination administered, and shall consist
of: (1) the Mayor, (2) the Chief of the Fire Department, and (3) the President
of Council in the case of the Police Department. The Review Committee shall be
formed prior to the date of the administration of the competency examination.
   (b)   The outside examiner(s) chosen by the Mayor shall score the written
portion of the professional competency examination and assign a pass/fail grade
to the physical ability examination, if applicable.
   (c)   The panel interview, if applicable, shall be scored pursuant to an
independently established scoring procedure. For initial appointments in the
Fire Department, the panel interview may be conducted by: (1) a shift officer
designated by the Chief, (2) a representative of an appropriate outside entity
tasked with interacting with the Fire Department, as designated by the Mayor,
and (3) the fire chief of another agency as designated by the Mayor.
   (d)   The Review Committee shall then add all applicable credits, pursuant
to Section
246.09 of this chapter, to the professional competency examination score of the
remaining eligible applicants, creating a total point score. After the credits
have been applied, the Review Committee shall prepare a list ranking the
applicants, from highest to lowest total point score. In the event that two or
more applicants receive the same total point score, including credit points,
priority shall be determined by lot. The Review Committee shall then certify
the list as the eligibility list for the applicable position in the Police or
Fire Department.
   (e)   This eligibility list shall be immediately posted by the Village
Administration at the Village Hall and in the Police or Fire Department, as
applicable. The final results of all examinations and calculation of credits
shall be kept on file in the office of the Mayor.
(Ord. 2012-32. Passed 5-9-12; Ord. 2017-98. Passed 12-13-17; Ord. 2018-14.
Passed 1- 10-18; Ord. 2019-81. Passed 10-9-19.)
246.09 CREDITS.
   (a)   Credits for Initial Appointments. The following credit points shall be
added to the passing competency examination scores of initial appointment
applicants:
      (1)   Ohio Peace Officer Training Certificate. An additional credit of
five points shall be given to all applicants for initial appointment in the
Police Department if the applicant has a current, valid certificate issued by
the Executive Director of the Ohio Peace Officer Training Council pursuant to
Ohio R.C. 109.75, as amended. Proof of possession of the aforesaid certificate
shall be submitted by the applicant at the time of application under Section
246.04 of this chapter. If the applicant for the Police Department is eligible
to receive such credit, the applicant shall have maintained said certificate in
good standing between the time of his or her application and the time of his or
her appointment, to maintain his or her entitlement to the credit.
      (2)   Education Credit for Fire Department. An additional credit of five
points shall be given to any applicant for initial appointment in the Fire
Department who has attained an Associate's Degree in the field of Fire
Technology from a certified full-time college or university.
      (3)   Credit for Part-Time Employment with the Village. An additional
credit of one-half point for each year of continuous service as a part-time
Village firefighter, up to a maximum of eight points, shall be given to any
applicant for initial full-time employment in the Fire Department who,
immediately before applying for initial full-time employment in the Village
Fire Department worked for at least one year as a part-time employee of the
Village Fire Department. For the Police Department, an additional credit of
five points shall be given to any applicant for initial appointment to the
Police Department if the applicant has worked continuously as a part-time
police officer in the Police Department in the each of the twenty-four months
immediately preceding the evaluation of candidates for initial appointment.
      (4)   Military service. An additional credit offive points shall be given
to all applicants for initial appointment who can show proof of honorable
discharge from service in the uniformed services. “Uniformed services” shall
mean the United States Armed Forces (Army, Navy, Air Force, Marine Corps and
Coast Guard), the Army National Guard and the Air National Guard, the
Commissioned Corps of the Public Health Service, and other categories of
persons designated by the President of the United States (or Governor of a
state in, or territory of, the United States) in time of war or national
emergency. Proof of possession of the aforesaid certification shall be
submitted by the applicant at the time of application under Section
246.04 .
      (5)   Maximum Credits Available for Initial Appointments. There shall be
a maximum of ten credit points added to the passing competency examination
scores of initial appointment applicants.
   (b)   Credits for Promotions. Applicants for promotion to the position of
Lieutenant in the Police Department shall receive on the written portion of the
examination, one credit point for each year of service from the fifth year of
service to the twenty-fifth year of service, with a maximum of 20 points
allowed. After consultation with the Village Administration and staff, and
after due consideration of a candidate’s performance during an individual
interview, the Mayor may award up to five total administrative points to the
scores of the applicants for promotion. The five administrative points may be
allocated among the candidates as the Mayor chooses.
(Ord. 2012-32. Passed 5-9-12; Ord. 2014-19. Passed 2-12-14; Ord. 2016-46.
Passed 6-8- 16; Ord. 2017-98. Passed 12-13-17; Ord. 2019-81. Passed 10-9-19;
Ord. 2020-69. Passed 9-9-20.)
246.10 APPOINTMENTS FROM THE ELIGIBILITY LIST.
   (a)   Initial Appointments.
      (1)   When there is a vacancy or a vacancy appears imminent in the Police
or Fire Department in a position to be filled by an initial appointment, the
Mayor shall review the standing eligibility list and then name candidates for
appointment pursuant to division (a)(2) of this section. The named candidates
shall then complete the psychological and physical health examinations pursuant
to Section
246.06(a)(3) and may be subject to a lie detector test administered by a
company designated by the Village. The Mayor, either solely or with the
assistance of the chief of the department for which the appointment will be
made, or any other Village officer, may conduct interviews of the candidates.
      (2)   When only one position is to be filled, the Mayor shall appoint
from the top ten candidates on the eligibility list. If more than one position
is to be filled, the Mayor shall appoint from the top fifteen candidates who
remain on the list and who are willing to accept consideration for the
position. In the extraordinary circumstance where all candidates eligible for
consideration for appointment based upon the foregoing methodology are not, in
the Mayor's sole discretion, acceptable candidates for the position, the Mayor
may proceed down the eligibility list in order until an acceptable candidate is
found.
      (3)   Should a candidate refuse, for any reason, to accept appointment in
the Fire or Police Departments when first offered by the Mayor, such
candidate's name shall be removed from the eligible list, and such candidate
shall be ineligible to be reinstated on such list. After the expiration of such
eligible list, the candidate shall be eligible to reapply to take any
subsequent examination for initial appointment in the Fire or Police
Departments. A person who has been considered for appointment by the Mayor from
an eligibility list more than three times to the same position may be omitted
from future consideration by the Mayor. When the number of persons on the
eligibility list is less than the number from which the Mayor may choose, under
subsection (a)(2) above, appointment from that eligibility list shall not be
mandatory and a new eligibility list may be created pursuant to the process set
forth in this chapter.
   (b)   Promotional Appointments. Promotional appointments shall be made
pursuant to Section
246.07.
(Ord. 2012-32. Passed 5-9-12; Ord. 2012-81. Passed 8-8-12; Ord. 2017-98. Passed
12-13-17.)
246.11 PROBATIONARY PERIODS.
   (a)   The probationary period for initial appointments in the Police
Department shall extend for 365 days from the date of employment, exclusive of
days conducting Ohio Peace Officer Training pursuant to Ohio R.C. 109.75, as
amended. If the appointee holds a valid, current Ohio Peace Officer Certificate
at the time of the appointment, the probationary period shall be for 365 days
from the time of the initial appointment.
   (b)   The probationary period for all initial appointments in the Fire
Department shall be 365 days from the date of employment, except that the
probationary period shall not be considered successfully completed until, among
all other requirements, the appointee obtains a certificate of competency in
Emergency Medical Technician - Paramedic, as required by Section
246.12 and Ohio R.C. 4765.30 and 4765.39, as amended.
   (c)   Promotional appointments in the Police or Fire Department, with the
exception of the Police Chief and Fire Chief, shall be subject to a
probationary period of one year. Such period may be extended by the Mayor with
the approval of Council for good cause shown by the Police Chief or Fire Chief
for a period not to exceed an additional six months.
   (d)   No initial appointment or promotion shall be deemed final until the
appointee has successfully served his or her probationary period. At the end of
the probationary period, the Chief of the department will transmit to the Mayor
a record of the employee's service, together with a recommendation as to
whether the employee has satisfactorily served his or her probationary period.
The Mayor will then make a determination as to whether the appointee has
satisfactorily served his or her probationary period. If such service is
satisfactory, the appointee shall continue in his or her rank.
   (e)   If, at the end of the probationary period, the appointee's service is
deemed unsatisfactory by the Mayor, then with the approval of Council, he or
she shall be terminated from the department if he or she had received an
initial appointment in the Police Department, or he or she shall be reduced to
the rank held at the time he or she was appointed to the higher rank if he or
she received a promotional appointment. In all cases of unsatisfactory
probationary periods, the Mayor shall furnish the employee with written notice
of an unsatisfactory probation and a statement of the basis for such finding.
(Ord. 2012-32. Passed 5-9-12; Ord. 2017-98. Passed 12-13-17.)
246.12 EMT AND PARAMEDIC REQUIREMENTS IN THE FIRE DEPARTMENT.
   (a)   After April 1, 1987, any person receiving an initial appointment as a
member of the Fire Department shall be required, during his or her probationary
period, to complete a program of instruction and obtain a certificate to
practice as an Emergency Medical Technician - Paramedic, pursuant to Ohio R.C.
4765.30 and 4765.39, as amended, if such person does not already possess the
certificate to practice as a Paramedic. The Clerk is authorized to pay for the
initial program of instruction for the appointee. If the appointee is unable to
obtain a certificate to practice as an Emergency Medical Technician - Paramedic
after two separate tests, he or she shall be deemed to have unsatisfactorily
completed his or her probationary period and he or she shall be terminated from
the department pursuant to Section
246.11.
   (b)   Any member of the Fire Department who was employed prior to April 1,
1987, shall not be required, as a condition of employment, to maintain a valid
certificate to practice as an Emergency Medical Technician - Paramedic pursuant
to Ohio R.C. 4765.30 and 4765.39, as amended.
   (c)   All full-time members of the Fire Department hired after April 1,
1987, shall, as a condition of employment in the Fire Department, after
successful completion of their probationary periods and through the first nine
years of service with the Fire Department, be required to maintain a
certificate to practice as an Emergency Medical Technician - Paramedic,
pursuant to Ohio R.C. 4765.30 and 4765.39, as amended.
(Ord. 2012-32. Passed 5-9-12.)
246.13 OHIO PEACE OFFICER TRAINING CERTIFICATE REQUIREMENTS IN THE POLICE
DEPARTMENT.
   As a condition employment in the Police Department, all initial members of
the Police Department must obtain a valid certificate issued by the Executive
Director of the Ohio Peace Officer Training Council pursuant to Ohio R.C.
109.75, as amended, unless the appointee holds a current, valid certificate at
the time of his or her appointment. The appointee shall have two attempts to
pass the examination for the certificate within the first year of service in
the Police Department. If the appointee is unable to obtain the certificate
after the two attempts to pass the examination, the appointee shall be deemed
to have unsatisfactorily completed the probationary period and the appointee
shall be terminated from the department pursuant to Section
246.11. The Village Clerk is authorized to pay for the initial program of
instruction, provided that the applicant does not hold a valid certificate at
the time of his or her initial appointment.
(Ord. 2012-32. Passed 5-9-12.)
246.14 FULL-TIME POLICE DISPATCHER REQUIREMENTS.
   (a)   The Village shall at all times have a standing list of persons
eligible for new hire full- time Police Dispatcher positions. Competitive
examinations for full-time Police Dispatcher positions shall be conducted on
the third Saturday of June in every even-numbered year. If the Mayor, in his or
her discretion, determines that conducting the examination on said date is
impracticable, the Mayor shall schedule the examination to be held on another
date within three months, before or after, said date. Additional examinations
may be administered if a vacancy cannot be filled by the standing list of
eligible persons or if the standing list of eligible persons contains less than
ten names. All eligibility lists shall become effective upon the approval and
posting of the eligibility list and shall remain in effect for a period of two
years or until a new eligibility list is posted, whichever occurs earlier.
Council may extend the effective date of any eligibly list through legislative
action.
   (b)   No person shall be eligible to take an examination for original
appointment as a full-time Police Dispatcher unless he or she is at least 21
years of age, has obtained a high school diploma or an Ohio GED equivalent, and
is a natural born or naturalized citizen of the United States. The Mayor, with
the approval of Council, may refuse to allow an applicant to be examined, or
after an examination may refuse to consider an applicant for the position who
is found to lack any of the established preliminary requirements for the
examination; who is unable to perform the essential functions of the position
with or without a reasonable accommodation; who is a current user of illegal
drugs; who has been convicted of a felony; who has been guilty of infamous or
notoriously disgraceful conduct; who has been dismissed from any public
position for delinquency or misconduct; or who has made false statements of any
material fact or practiced or attempted to practice any deception or fraud in
his or her application or in his or her examination in establishing his or her
eligibility or securing his or her appointment.
   (c)   Each applicant seeking initial appointment as a full-time Police
Dispatcher shall file with the Mayor a formal application in which the
applicant shall state under oath or affirmation as follows:
      (1)   His or her full name, residence and post office address;
      (2)   His or her age, place of birth and date of birth;
      (3)   His or her business employment and residence for the previous five
years; and
      (4)   Such other information as may be reasonably required pertaining to
the applicant's fitness for the position sought.
   (d)   Blank forms for an application shall be furnished by the Mayor without
charge to any person eligible to take the examination. All applications shall
be filed with the Mayor in duplicate and one copy, receipted by the Mayor,
shall be returned to the applicant.
   (e)   The Mayor, with the assistance of either or both the Police Chief and
Fire Chief if the Mayor desires, shall conduct a professional competency
examination for all applicants for the position. Such examination shall be
practical in character, maybe written and/or oral and shall relate directly to
those matters which fairly test the capacity of the person examined to
discharge the particular duties of a Police Dispatcher. Reasonable notice of
the time, place and general scope of the competitive examination shall be given
by the Mayor. At a minimum, such notices shall be posted in a conspicuous place
in the Village Hall and in the Fire and Police Departments at least two weeks
prior to the examination.
   (f)   A three-person Review Committee shall create the eligibility list,
consisting of: (1) the Mayor, (2) the Chief of the Fire Department or the
Police Department, chosen at the Mayor's discretion, and (3) the President of
Council. From the results of the examinations, the Review Committee shall
prepare an eligibility list of persons who have passed the examination by a
grade of 70 points or better (70% on a 100% scale). The following credit points
shall then be added to the candidate's score if applicable:
      (1)   An additional credit of five points to any applicant if the
applicant has a current, valid LEADS/NCIC certification; and
      (2)   Uniformed services credits pursuant to Section
246.09(a)(4).
   (g)   The Review Committee shall then rank the list of candidates in the
order of their relative excellence as determined by the examination with the
relevant bonus points added. In the event that two or more applicants for
initial appointment receive the same total point score, inclusive of credits,
priority shall be determined by lot. This eligibility list shall then be
approved by the Review Committee and immediately posted in the Village Hall and
in the Police and Fire Departments.
   (h)   When there is a vacancy or a vacancy appears imminent for the position
of a full-time Police Dispatcher, the Mayor shall be notified of the vacancy.
The Mayor shall review the standing eligibility list and then name the
candidate for appointment. The Mayor shall appoint from the top ten candidates
on the eligibility list. In the extraordinary circumstance where all candidates
eligible for consideration for appointment based upon the foregoing methodology
are not, in the Mayor's sole discretion, acceptable candidates for the
position, the Mayor may proceed down the eligibility list in order until an
acceptable candidate is found. In the event that an applicant refuses, for any
reason, appointment to the position of full-time Dispatcher, his or her name
shall be stricken from the eligibility list and such candidate shall be
ineligible to be reinstated on such list. After the expiration of such
eligibility list, the candidate shall be eligible to reapply to take any
subsequent examination for initial appointment as a full-time Police
Dispatcher. A person who has been considered for appointment by the Mayor from
an eligibility list more than three times to the same position may be omitted
from future consideration by the Mayor.
   (i)   Prior to an appointment, the Mayor shall cause the eligible applicant
to be examined by an outside medical officer selected by the Village, who shall
prepare a report which shall show that the applicant is both physical,
mentally, and psychologically fit to perform his or her duties as a Police
Dispatcher and the Mayor may cause the applicant to take a lie detector test
administered by a company designated by the Village.
   (j)   The probationary period for the position of full-time Police
Dispatcher shall be one year from the time of appointment and shall be
determined according to the provisions of Section
246.11.
   (k)   Unless otherwise stated, the appointment, promotion, demotion or
removal of Dispatchers shall be subject to the executive powers of the Mayor as
set forth in Section
230.01.
(Ord. 2012-32. Passed 5-9-12; Ord. 2012-81. Passed 8-8-12; Ord. 2014-19. Passed
2-12-14.)
246.15 PART-TIME POLICE DISPATCHER REQUIREMENTS.
   (a)   No person shall be eligible for an original appointment as a part-time
Police Dispatcher unless he or she is at least 21 years of age, has obtained a
high school diploma or Ohio GED equivalent, and is a natural born or
naturalized citizen of the United States. The Mayor may refuse to consider an
applicant for the position who is found to lack any of the established
preliminary requirements for the examination; who is unable to perform the
essential functions of the position with or without a reasonable accommodation;
who is a current user of illegal drugs; who has been convicted of a felony; who
has been guilty of infamous or notoriously disgraceful conduct; who has been
dismissed from any public position for delinquency or misconduct; or who has
made false statements of any material fact or practiced or attempted to
practice any deception or fraud in his or her application or in his or her
examination in establishing his or her eligibility or securing his or her
appointment.
   (b)   Each applicant seeking an initial appointment as a part-time Police
Dispatcher shall file with the Mayor a formal application in accordance with
Section
246.14(c). LEADS certification is preferred, but not required for appointment.
   (c)   Prior to an appointment, the Mayor shall cause the eligible applicant
to be examined by an outside medical officer selected by the Village, who shall
prepare a report which shall show that the applicant is physically fit to
perform his or her duties as a Police Dispatcher and shall cause the applicant
to take a lie detector test administered by a company designated by the
Village.
   (d)   Unless otherwise stated, the appointment, promotion, demotion or
removal of part-time Police Dispatchers shall be subject to the executive
powers of the Mayor as set forth in Section
230.01.
(Ord. 2012-32. Passed 5-9-12.)
246.16 LATERAL TRANSFERS.
   Notwithstanding anything in this chapter regarding original appointments and
promotions, the Mayor/Safety Director is separately authorized to make
appointments in the Fire Department and Police Department by lateral transfer.
Council authorizes the Mayor/Safety Director to create policies to determine
the eligibility for and selection of lateral transfers in the Fire Department
and the Police Department, and to utilize those policies as-needed in
appointing lateral transfers.
(Ord. 2024-52. Passed 8-14-24.)
CHAPTER 248
Service Department

Resolution 1998-31, passed February 11, 1998. Copies may be obtained, at cost,
from the Village Clerk.
