248.01 COMPOSITION; APPOINTMENTS; DUTIES; HOURS OF WORK; ABSENCE OF SERVICE
DIRECTOR.
   (a)   Composition.
      (1)   The Service Department shall consist of a Service Director, an
Assistant Service Director, one skilled maintenance employee, one mechanic, one
head landscaper, not more than five full-time laborers designated as "Laborer
I", one skilled apprentice, not more than two full-time laborers designated as
"Laborer II", and one Laborer/Recreation Coordinator/Operations Support
employee. Collectively, the total number of full-time employees of the Service
Department shall not exceed fourteen employees.
      (2)   The Service Department may also include such number of part-time
mechanics, part-time skilled mechanic/skilled maintenance employee(s), part-
time laborers, and part-time bus-drivers as may be appointed by the Mayor,
pursuant to Section 248.02, at the request of the Service Director for good
cause shown.
   (b)   Appointment; Duties. The Service Director, Assistant Service Director,
and any employees listed in Chapter 248 shall serve as prescribed in Section
230.01. They shall perform such duties as may from time to time be assigned to
them by the Mayor.
   (c)   Hours of Work. The minimum hours of work for which the Service
Director, the Assistant Service Director, and any employees listed in Section
248.01(a)(1) shall be required to perform their duties shall be eight hours per
weekday, a total of 40 hours per calendar week.
   (d)   Absence of Service Director. In the absence of the Service Director,
the Assistant Service Director shall be in charge of the Department. In the
event that both the Service Director and the Assistant Service Director are
unavailable, the Mayor or his designee may appoint a Service Department
employee to be in charge of the Service Department during that period when both
the Service Director and the Assistant Service Director are unavailable.
(Ord. 1998-140. Passed 11-9-98; Ord. 2005-193. Passed 12-14-05; Ord. 2006-82.
Passed 6-7-06; Ord. 2008-111. Passed 6-11-08; Ord. 2009-146. Passed 10-14-09;
Ord. 2010-43. Passed 4-14-10; Ord. 2015-34. Passed 5-13-15; Ord. 2017-69.
Passed 9-13-17; Ord. 2018-71. Passed 8-8-18; Ord. 2018-97. Passed 11-14-18;
Ord. 2022-21. Passed 2-9-22.)
248.02 QUALIFICATIONS FOR PART-TIME EMPLOYMENT.
   The Mayor, from time to time, shall have the authority to hire persons for
part- time employment in the Service Department. The Mayor may refuse to
consider an applicant for the position of part-time bus driver who is a current
user of illegal drugs; who has been convicted of a felony; who has been guilty
of infamous or notoriously disgraceful conduct; who has been dismissed from any
public position for delinquency or misconduct; or who has made false statements
of any material fact or has practiced, or attempted to practice, any deception
or fraud in the applicant's application or examination in establishing the
applicant's ability or in securing said appointment.
(Ord. 1993-37. Passed 3-10-93; Ord. 2008-114. Passed 6-11-08; Ord. 2009-162.
Passed 11-11-09; Ord. 2013-69. Passed 8-14-13.)
248.03 UNIFORM ALLOWANCES.
   (a)   At the Village’s expense, and subject to the Mayor’s approval, the
Service Director, the Assistant Service Director, and any employees listed in
Section 248.01(a)(1) shall be permitted to rent uniforms for their regular work
duties.
   (b)   In the Service Department, an allowance for only the following
employees may be made in each year, if needed, unless otherwise indicated, for
not more than the following:
   Service Director, Assistant Service Director, and any employees listed in
Section 248.01(a)(1):
   Clothing allowance not to exceed five hundred dollar ($500.00) limit in one
year.
   (c)   The Service Director shall create a policy to govern the annual
uniform allowance available to part-time Service Department employees.
(Ord. 2005-79. Passed 5-11-05; Ord. 2006-99. Passed 6-7-06; Ord. 2008-113.
Passed 6-11-08; Ord. 2009-146. Passed 10-14-09; Ord. 2010-43. Passed 4-14-10;
Ord. 2014-25. Passed 2-12-14; Ord. 2017-69. Passed 9-13-17; Ord. 2018-71.
Passed 8-8-18; Ord. 2018-97. Passed 11-14-18; Ord. 2022-21. Passed 2-9-22.)
248.04 SHOW-UP TIME FOR SERVICE ON OFF-DUTY HOURS.
   When a full-time member of the Service Department is called in for duty
during his or her normal off-duty hours, such member shall be entitled to show-
up time of a minimum of two hours.
(Ord. 1998-50. Passed 3-11-98; Ord. 2008-115. Passed 6-11-08; Ord. 2010-43.
Passed 4-14-10; Ord. 2025-49. Passed 8-13-25.)
248.05 CDL LICENSE FEE REIMBURSEMENT.
   (a)   Each full-time employee in the Service Department who successfully
obtains a CDL license shall be reimbursed by the Village for the fees involved
in obtaining and renewing such license.
   (b)   In order to be entitled to reimbursement, the employee shall be
required to present appropriate receipts and documentation to the Chief Fiscal
Officer.
(Ord. 1998-65. Passed 4-8-98; Ord. 2017-69. Passed 9-13-17.)
248.06 TREE TRIMMING AND TREE REMOVAL SERVICE FOR RESIDENTS OF THE VILLAGE.
   (a)   The Service Director is hereby authorized and directed to receive
proposals on a bi-yearly basis for a program for tree trimming and tree removal
service to the residents of the Village on an as-needed basis.
   (b)   The Mayor, with the approval of Council, is authorized to accept
proposals for tree trimming and tree removal on a bi-yearly basis.
   (c)   The Clerk is to place a notice in the Cuyahoga Heights Village News
Letter notifying the residents of the program and a form for the residents to
request this service, if needed.
   (d)   The limit of the number of tree trimming and removals per year per
residential lot shall be as follows: one removal and two trims per calendar
year for each property owner.
   (e)   Upon receiving emergency service requests based on an act of nature,
the Service Director shall prioritize and schedule based on the severity of the
threat to property, environment or safety. These emergency service requests
will not count towards the limit set in division (d) of this section.
   (f)   The Service Director, or his or her designee, shall compile a tree
trimming and tree removal list and schedule the tree trimming and tree removal
services so that the appointed professional tree service can provide a full day
of services when working. The Service Director's list shall prioritize the work
to be performed based on the severity of the threat to public property, the
environment or safety and any past services rendered under this program.
   (g)   A property owner, before any trimming, must submit an application,
waiver of liability and right of entry before removal may occur on private
property. All forms shall be subject to the review and approval of the Law
Director.
(Ord. 2001-37. Passed 4-11-01; Ord. 2008-65. Passed 4-9-08.)
248.07 PHYSICAL EXAMINATIONS REQUIRED.
   The Mayor shall require all full-time members of the Service Department to
be examined by an outside medical officer of his or her choice at intervals of
no less than two years.
(Ord. 2002-80. Passed 6-12-02.)
248.08 DUMP FEE REIMBURSEMENT.
   The Chief Fiscal Officer is hereby authorized and directed to collect a
reasonable dump fee reimbursement from any resident who wishes an extraordinary
refuse pick-up.
(Ord. 2002-151. Passed 11-13-02; Ord. 2017-69. Passed 9-13-17.)
248.09 BONUS COMPENSATION.
   Except for the Service Director and Assistant Service Director, members of
the Service Department who have possessed, during the entire calendar year, a
current, valid Commercial Driver's license shall receive a bonus of an
additional sum of money as follows: seven hundred dollars ($700.00) per year
for Service Department employees who worked the entire year as a full-time
employee of the Service Department; and two hundred dollars ($200.00) per year
for Service Department employees who worked the entire year as a permanent
part-time employee of the Service Department. If an employee transitions from a
permanent part-time position to a full-time position within the Service
Department (or vice-versa), and the employee remains an employee for the entire
calendar year, then the employee’s bonus compensation shall be adjusted
proportionally to account for the time worked as a permanent part-time and
full-time Service Department employee. Payment to be upon a pro-rata basis upon
retirement, disability or death.
(Ord. 2020-101. Passed 12-9-20.)

250.02 VILLAGE NURSE.

to such position shall be made by the Mayor, subject to the approval of
Council. Such appointment shall be for such period of time and under the
conditions as may be determined at the time of appointment. The Village Nurse
shall serve at the pleasure of the Mayor and shall be subject to termination by

screening.

CHAPTER 252

252.01 ADMINISTRATIVE ASSISTANT TO THE MAYOR.
   (a)   Establishment of Position. There is hereby established a position to
be known as the Administrative Assistant to the Mayor.
   (b)   Duties. The duties incident to the position of Administrative
Assistant to the Mayor shall be to render secretarial assistance to the Mayor,
act as his or her receptionist, assist the Clerk and other Village officials,
in such manner and to such extent as the Mayor may from time to time specify,
and perform such other and additional duties and functions as the Mayor may
from time to time require or designate.
   (c)   Appointment; Term. The Administrative Assistant to the Mayor shall be
appointed by the Mayor, subject to the approval of Council, and shall serve at
the pleasure of the Mayor.
(Ord. 1971-07. Passed 1-13-71.)
252.02 CLERICAL ASSISTANT TO THE CLERK.
   (a)   Establishment of Position. There is hereby established a position to
be known as the Clerical Assistant to the Clerk.
   (b)   Duties. The duties of the Clerical Assistant to the Clerk shall be to
render clerical assistance to the Clerk, the Administrative Assistant to the
Mayor, the Administrative Assistant to the Village Hall and other Village
officials, in such manner and to such extent as the Mayor or Clerk may from
time to time require or designate.
(Ord. 1982-19. Passed 2-24-82.)
   (c)   Appointment; Term. The Clerical Assistant to the Clerk shall be
appointed and shall serve as prescribed in Section
230.01.
(Ord. 1990-105. Passed 10-10-90; Ord. 2010-71. Passed 7-14-10.)
252.03 ADMINISTRATIVE ACCOUNTING ASSISTANT.
   (a)   Establishment of Position. There is hereby established the position of
Administrative Accounting Assistant, which position may be held by one or more
employee at any given time.
   (b)   Duties. Effective January 1, 2018, the duties of the Administrative
Accounting Assistant shall be to render administrative, accounting, and payroll
assistance to the Chief Fiscal Officer, in such manner and to such extent as
the Mayor may from time to time require or designate.
   (c)   Appointment; Term. The Administrative Accounting Assistant position
shall be appointed and shall serve as prescribed in Section
230.01 .
(Ord. 1990-105. Passed 10-10-90; Ord. 2006-95. Passed 6-7-06; Ord. 2010-71.
Passed 7-14-10; Ord. 2017-12. Passed 2-8-17; Ord. 2017-83. Passed 12-13-17.)

252.06 PHYSICAL EXAMINATIONS REQUIRED.
   The Mayor shall require all full-time employees of the Village to be
examined by an outside medical officer of his or her choice at intervals of no
less than two years.
(Ord. 2002-80. Passed 6-12-02.)
252.07 RECREATION MANAGER.
   (a)   Establishment of Position. There is hereby established a position to
be known as the Recreation Manager.
   (b)   Duties. The Recreation Manager shall be responsible for organizing,
administering, and coordinating all recreational activities in the Village,
including pool management and sporting activities, and shall provide periodic
reports to Council and/or the Mayor about such recreational activities in the
Village. The Recreation Manager shal perform additional duties as required by
the Mayor.
   (c)   Appointment; Term. The Recreation Manager shall be appointed by the
Mayor and approved by a majority vote of the Council. The Recreation Manager
shall serve a two-year term.
(Ord. 2006-77. Passed 4-12-06; Ord. 2017-83. Passed 12-13-17; Ord. 2018-86.
Passed 10-10-18.)
252.08 ASSISTANT BUILDING COMMISSIONER.
   (a)   Establishment of Position. There is hereby established a position to
be known as the Assistant Building Commissioner.
   (b)   Duties. The Assistant Building Commissioner shall assist the Building
Commissioner in enforcing the provisions of the Village Building and Housing
Code, examining plans, reviewing and issuing permits, maintaining a record of
the business of the Building Department, and performing such other additional
duties and functions delegated to him or her by the Building Commissioner.
   (c)   Appointment. The Assistant Building Commissioner shall be appointed by
the Mayor and approved by a majority vote of the Council.
(Ord. 2015-12. Passed 2-11-15.)
252.09 ADMINISTRATIVE ASSISTANT TO VILLAGE HALL.
   (a)   Establishment of Position. There is hereby established a position to
be known as the Administrative Assistant to Village Hall.
   (b)   Duties. The duties incident to the position of Administrative
Assistant to Village Hall shall be to render administrative assistance to the
Village employees and elected officials working at Village Hall, and perform
such other and additional duties and functions as the Mayor may from time to
time require or designate.
   (c)   Appointment; Term. The Administrative Assistant to Village Hall shall
be appointed by the Mayor, subject to the approval of Council, and shall serve
at the pleasure of the Mayor.
(Ord. 2018-98. Passed 11-14-18.)

254.01 VACATIONS.
   (a)   Except as otherwise provided in this Administration Code, or as set
forth in a collective bargaining agreement in effect at the time that vacation
time was earned, each person employed by the Village on a salary and on a full-
time basis shall be entitled to a vacation, with pay, in accordance with the
following schedule:
   Administrative: Full-Time (40 Hours Per Week)
   0 through 1 year of service completed         0 working days (exception in
subsection (e) hereof)
   start of 2 through 5 years of service completed      12 working days
   start of 6 through 10 years of service completed      21 working days
   start of 11 through 15 years of service completed      26 working days
   start of 16 years of service completed and beyond      33 working days
(Ord. 1993-37. Passed 3-10-93.)
   (b)   Except as otherwise provided in this Administration Code or as set
forth in a collective bargaining agreement in effect at the time that vacation
time was earned, the following persons employed by the Village on a salary and
on a thirty-hour or thirty-two hour per week basis shall be entitled to a
vacation, with pay, in accordance with the following schedule:
Part-Time Dispatchers Hired Prior to May 11, 2005 (32 Hours Per Week)
      0 through 1 year of service completed            0 working days
      start of 2 through 5 years of service completed         10 working days
      start of 6 through 10 years of service completed         17 working days
      start of 11 through 15 years of service completed         21 working days
      start of 16 years of service completed and beyond         27 working days
(Ord. 1998-15. Passed 1-14-98.)
   (c)   All vacations must be taken by Village employees during the calendar
year of entitlement and shall not accrue from year to year. All Village
employees who have served less than one year shall be entitled to no vacation.
(Ord. 1993-37. Passed 3-10-93; Ord. 2005-79. Passed 5-11-05; Ord. 2017-83.
Passed 12-13-17.)
254.02 PAYMENT FOR UNUSED VACATION TIME.
   If, during any calendar year, due to an extraordinary job-related illness,
an accident or other circumstance, a Village employee is unable to use his or
her entire vacation time, he or she may be paid for his or her accumulated and
unused vacation time as set forth in this section. Such payment may be made
during the first four months of the next succeeding year and may be made only
if the employee has obtained the prior written approval of the Mayor during the
calendar year of entitlement for the vacation.
(Ord. 1993-37. Passed 3-10-93; Ord. 2017-83. Passed 12-13-17.)
254.03 TIME TRACKING MECHANISMS FOR CERTAIN EMPLOYEES; VIOLATIONS.
   (a)   All non-bargaining full-time employees of the Village Hall, Building
Department, Finance Department, Police Department, Fire Department, Service
Department and Parks and Recreation Department, (except the Chief Fiscal
Officer, Building Commissioner, Police Chief, Deputy Chief, Fire Chief,
Assistant Fire Chief, Service Director, Assistant Service Director and Parks
and Recreation Director), shall be provided a mechanism for tracking their time
spent performing job duties, and shall utilize that time tracking mechanism as
directed to ensure that their time spent performing job duties is fully,
accurately, and honestly recorded. No employee shall make a time entry for
another employee.
   Compensation for portions of an hour shall be fixed as follows: the hours
shall be divided into increments of fifteen minutes per hour with the employee
to receive 25% of the hourly rate. The Mayor, Chief Fiscal Officer, Police
Chief, Fire Chief, Service Director, or Parks and Recreation Director shall
approve employee entries into such time tracking mechanisms prior to the
payment of compensation for the employee. No employee shall modify, alter, or
amend a time entry, unless necessary to make a correction, and any such
correction must first be approved by the department head or designee. No
employee shall make a time entry for another employee.
   (b)   Violations of the foregoing rules shall subject the employee to
immediate dismissal. No compensation shall be paid for time which is not
indicated on the time cards showing the commencement and termination of the
hours of labor claimed.
(Ord. 1993-37. Passed 3-10-93; Ord. 2007-166. Passed 11-14-07; Ord. 2010-71.
Passed 7-14-10; Ord. 2017-83. Passed 12-13-17; Ord. 2018-86. Passed 10-10-18;
Ord. 2025-14. Passed 2-12-25.)
254.04 BONDS.
   (a)   Use of Blanket Bond. All employees and elected and appointed officers
of the Village, with the exception of the officers and employees listed in
subsection (d) of this Section
254.04 , shall be covered under the provisions of a public employees' blanket
bond in lieu of the execution of individual bonds conditioned upon the faithful
performance of their offices and duties. No bond shall be required for the
Director of Law, Assistant Director of Law, Prosecutor, or members of Council.
   (b)   Amount of Blanket Bond. The public employees' blanket bond shall be
executed in favor of the Village by a surety company authorized to issue surety
and fidelity bonds in the State, and shall be in the amount of five thousand
dollars ($5,000) for each position or office held by an employee or officer of
the Village, other than those officials excepted by the provisions of
subsection (a) hereof, and shall be approved by the Mayor and Solicitor.
   (c)   Conditions of Blanket Bond. The public employees' blanket bond
provided for herein shall be conditioned upon the faithful performance of the
duties and offices of the individually covered officers and employees, and upon
the accounting for and paying over to the proper officer of the Village all
monies and other property coming into the possession of the individually
covered officers and employees and belonging to the Village.
   (d)   Individual Bonds. Individual bonds conditioned upon the faithful
performance of the duties and offices of the officers excepted from the
coverage of the public employees' blanket bond by the provisions of division
(a) of this section shall be executed by such officers, with approved sureties,
in the amount of one hundred fifty thousand dollars ($150,000) for the Chief
Fiscal Officer and the Mayor, and twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000) each
for the Administrative Assistant to the Mayor, the Police Chief, the
Administrative Assistant to the Chief and Police Services, the Building
Commissioner, the Administrative Accounting Assistants, and the officer or
employee charged with the duties of the Clerk of Mayor's Court.
(Ord. 1993-37. Passed 3-10-93; Res. 1998-02. Passed 1-14-98; Res. 2000-09.
Passed 1-12-00; Res. 2002-10. Passed 1-9-02; Ord. 2002-168. Passed 12-11-02;
Ord. 2013-110. Passed 11-11-13; Ord. 2017-10. Passed 2-8-17; Ord. 2017-83.
Passed 12-13-17; Ord. 2024-76. Passed 12-11-24.)
254.05 HOSPITALIZATION INSURANCE AND OTHER HEALTH AND INSURANCE BENEFITS FOR
CERTAIN EMPLOYEES.
   (a)   In addition to regular salaries and compensation, all non-bargaining
full- time employees of the Village Hall, Building Department, Finance
Department, Police Department, Fire Department, Service Department and Parks
and Recreation Department shall be furnished, at Village expense, with a
general health insurance benefit plan package as shall be determined by Council
from time to time.
   (b)   All Village employees listed in division (a) of this section, who
participate in the Village hospitalization insurance program shall pay 5% of
the total monthly health insurance premium and be provided a health savings
account (HSA) available to individual employees and their eligible family
members under the same terms and conditions as those set forth in the
collective bargaining agreements between the Village and its collective
bargaining units.
   (c)   Except as otherwise provided in the Codified Ordinances, all part-time
elected Village officials shall be exempt from the provisions of Section
254.05(a) and shall not receive insurance at the Village expense under this
Section
254.05.
(Ord. 2000-156. Passed 12-13-00; Ord. 2005-79. Passed 5-11-05; Ord. 2005-82.
Passed 5-11-05; Ord. 2006-53. Passed 3-8-06; Ord. 2006-98. Passed 6-7-06; Ord.
2008-117. Passed 6-11-08; Ord. 2009-36. Passed 2-11-09; Ord. 2010-71. Passed 7-
14-10; Ord. 2017-83. Passed 12-13-17; Ord. 2018-99. Passed 11-14-18; Ord. 2019-
62. Passed 8-14- 19; Ord. 2025-14. Passed 2-12-25.)
254.06 COMPENSATION ON BIWEEKLY BASIS.
   (a)   All employees shall be paid on a biweekly basis with the pay period
ending on alternate Saturdays, except that the pay period for members of the
Police Department and Fire Department shall end on alternate Sundays.
(Ord. 1994-66. Passed 4-27-94; Ord. 2021-23. Passed 5-12-21.)
   (b)   The Chief Fiscal Officer is hereby authorized to make payment of
compensation on the basis provided in subsection (a) hereof, when he or she
deems it most administratively feasible to do so.
(Ord. 1993-37. Passed 3-10-93; Ord. 2012-10. Passed 2-8-12; Ord. 2017-83.
Passed 12-13-17.)
254.07 SICK LEAVE FOR FULL-TIME EMPLOYEES.
   (a)   For the purpose of calculating sick time earned, all full-time members
of the Fire Department, excluding the Fire Chief and Assistant Fire Chief,
shall earn .0690 hours of sick time for each hour worked, including overtime
hours.
(Adopting Ordinance)
   (b)   All non-bargaining full-time employees of the Village Hall, Building
Department, Finance Department, Police Department, Fire Chief and Assistant
Fire Chief, Service Department and Parks and Recreation Department, shall earn
.0575 hours of sick time for each hour worked, including overtime hours.
(Ord. 1998-16. Passed 1-14-98; Ord. 1998-140. Passed 11-9-98; Ord. 2018-71.
Passed 8-8-18; Ord. 2018-99. Passed 11-14-18; Ord. 2025-14. Passed 2-12-25.)
   (c)   Employees may use sick leave, upon approval of the responsible
department head, for absences due to personal illness, pregnancy, injury and
exposure to a contagious disease which could be communicated to other
employees, and to illness, injury or death in the employee's immediate family.
Absences due to death in the employee's immediate family, as defined in Section
254.11, which are compensated for as provided in Section
254.11, shall not be deducted from an employee's accumulated sick leave, but
absences due to death in an employee's immediate family in excess of those
allowed by the department head pursuant to Section
254.11 shall be deducted from an employee's accumulated sick leave.
   (d)   Unused sick leave shall accumulate from year to year. However, the
maximum cumulative sick leave credit for any employee shall be 375 days (eight
hours to be considered a day). When sick leave is used, it shall be deducted
from the employee's credit on the basis of one hour for every one hour of
absence from previously scheduled work. Council may increase sick leave credits
of an employee for good cause shown by the adoption of an appropriate
resolution.
   (e)   The previously accumulated sick leave of an employee who has been
separated from his or her employment by the Village may be placed to his or her
credit upon his or her re-employment by the Village, provided that such re-
employment takes place within ten years of the date on which the employee was
last terminated from service in the Village. An employee who transfers from
another public agency to the Village shall be credited with the unused balance
of his or her accumulated sick leave.
   (f)   The department head shall require an employee to furnish a
satisfactory affidavit to justify the use of sick leave. If medical attention
is required, a certificate stating the nature of the illness from a licensed
physician shall be required to justify the use of sick leave. Falsification of
either the affidavit or the physician's certificate shall be grounds for
disciplinary action, including dismissal. No sick leave may be granted to an
employee after termination of employment, except as otherwise provided upon
retirement under Section 254.09. For the purpose of computing the amount of
sick leave used, employees shall be debited with the actual number of hours of
absence from work.
   (g)   This section does not interfere with existing unused sick leave credit
in any agency of government where attendance records are maintained and credit
has been given to employees for unused sick leave.
(Ord. 2005-79. Passed 5-11-05; Ord. 2009-146. Passed 10-14-09; Ord. 2010-30.
Passed 3-10-10; Ord. 2010-71. Passed 7-14-10; Ord. 2010-59. Passed 6-9-10; Ord.
2013-18. Passed 2-13-13; Ord. 2014-24. Passed 2-12-14; Ord. 2014-40. Passed 3-
12-14; Ord. 2014-50. Passed 4-9-14; Ord. 2017-83. Passed 12-13-17.)
254.071 EMPLOYEE SICK LEAVE BANK.
   (a)   There is hereby established an employee sick leave bank in which any
employee of the Village, including bargaining unit members, may voluntarily
donate earned but unused sick leave time. The sick leave bank established
hereunder shall be separate and apart from any other sick leave bank
established pursuant to a collective bargaining agreement.
   (b)   Any employee who donates sick leave time to the sick leave bank shall
have his or her accrued sick leave time reduced by the amount of sick leave
time donated. Donated sick leave time shall be non-refundable to the donating
employee, except pursuant to subsection (c) hereof.
   (c)   Any employee may solicit for receipt of sick leave time from the sick
leave bank based on qualifying need, provided the employee must have exhausted
all other forms of pays, including but not limited to vacation, sick leave, or
other usable methods before receiving any sick leave time from the employee
sick leave bank.
   (d)   The Mayor shall administer the sick leave bank and shall establish
rules and procedures for donating sick leave time to, and receiving sick leave
time from, the employee sick leave bank.
(Ord. 2014-53. Passed 4-9-14; Ord. 2017-83. Passed 12-13-17.)
254.08 SICK LEAVE CREDIT FOR SERVICE-CONNECTED INJURIES.
   (a)   Subject to the provisions of Sections
254.081 through
254.083, and after the first six days of service-related disabilities as set
forth in Section
254.081 through
254.083, the sick leave credits of an employee who is injured during the
performance of his or her duties within the scope of his or her employment
shall not be reduced for any period of time that he or she is absent from work
because of such service-connected injury. "Injury" means physical damage
resulting from an accident, and also includes heart attacks or failures,
strokes or physical or mental illnesses or diseases, if the employee furnishes
a certificate from a physician that such injury is service-connected.
   (b)   In the event of a dispute as to whether an injury is service-connected
within the meaning of this section or whether an injury is deemed to have
resulted from hazardous or nonhazardous duties pursuant to Sections
254.081 or
254.082, such dispute shall be submitted to a Board of Appeals, consisting of
the Mayor and two members of Council to be selected by Council. If the injured
person is a member of the Fire Department, such Board shall be increased to
include two members of the Fire Department to be selected by the remaining
members of the Fire Department. If the injured person is a Police officer, such
Board shall be increased to include two police officers to be selected by the
remaining officers of the Police Department. If the injured person is a member
of the Service Department, such Board shall be increased to include two Service
Department employees to be selected by the remaining members of the Service
Department. If the injured person is a member of the Public Employees
Retirement System receiving sick leave credits pursuant to Section
254.07(b), such Board shall be increased to include two members of the Public
Employees Retirement system receiving sick leave credits pursuant to Section
254.07(b), to be selected by the remaining members of the Public Employees
Retirement System receiving sick leave credits pursuant to Section
254.07(b). The decision of the Board shall be final and conclusive.
(Ord. 1993-37. Passed 3-10-93; Ord. 2002-135. Passed 10-9-02; Ord. 2017-83.
Passed 12-13-17.)
254.081 DISABILITY LEAVE; SERVICE DEPARTMENT AND ALL EMPLOYEES UNDER PUBLIC
EMPLOYEES RETIREMENT SYSTEM.
   (a)   An employee who is disabled as a result of the performance of duties
within the scope of his or her employment as a Service Department employee of
the Village or a member of the Public Employees Retirement System receiving
sick leave credit pursuant to Section
254.07(b), if such disability prevents him or her from performing his or her
duties, shall be paid his or her regular compensation during the continuance of
such service-related disability, but for a period not to exceed 183 calendar
days from the date that such service-related disability was incurred. During
such disability leave, compensation shall be paid in accordance with this
section, whether or not the employee has accumulated sick leave. In the event
accumulated sick leave is available, however, and a service-related disability
within the meaning of this section is incurred, the first six says of said
service-related disability shall be charged to said employee's accumulated sick
leave credit, or if less than six days accumulated sick leave credit is
available, the existing sick leave credit then available shall be charged, and
any remaining service- related disability leave shall be charged to disability
leave. In no event will an employee receive more than his or her regular
compensation while on disability leave.
   (b)   Any employee who obtains a paid leave under this section shall file
for Workers' Compensation and sign a waiver, assigning to the Village those
sums of money (temporary total disability benefits) he or she would ordinarily
receive as weekly compensation as determined by law for those number of weeks
he or she receives benefits under this section.
   (c)   A certificate of the attending physician or surgeon, certifying to the
service- related disability and the cause thereof, shall be filed with the
employee's department head before the last day of each month in which such
disability occurred or continues, or more often, if requested to do so by the
employee's department head, and any employee receiving disability leave must,
as a condition thereof, submit to a physical or physicals by a physician or
surgeon chosen by the Village at any time.
(Ord. 2002-135. Passed 10-9-02; Ord. 2012-25. Passed 4-2-12; Ord. 2017-83.
Passed 12-13-17.)
254.09 PAYMENT FOR ACCUMULATED SICK LEAVE.
   (a)   When an employee of the Village retires, he or she shall be paid a
lump sum for his or her accumulated and unused sick leave as allowed under
Section
254.07; this shall be paid at seventeen dollars ($17.00) per hour not to exceed
1,500 hours (maximum of twenty-five thousand five hundred dollars
($25,500.00)). Any accumulated but unused sick leave beyond the cap of 1,500
hours shall be forfeited without compensation, or the employee may donate the
remaining hours to the sick time bank by completing a form with the Fiscal
Office.
   (b)   An employee shall be deemed retired within the meaning of this section
when he or she applies for and obtains a disability or retirement pension under
any pension plan afforded such employee as a result of his or her employment
with the Village. In the event of the death of an employee, the foregoing lump
sum payment shall be paid to his or her surviving spouse. If there is no
surviving spouse, such payment shall be paid to whomever the employee
designates as the beneficiary thereof in writing with the Village Chief Fiscal
Officer. In the absence of such written designation, such lump sum payment
shall be made to his or her estate.
(Ord. 2000-59. Passed 4-12-00; Ord. 2017-83. Passed 12-13-17; Ord. 2025-14.
Passed 2- 12-25; Ord. 2025-49. Passed 8-13-25.)
254.10 LUMP SUM PAYMENT FOR VACATION TIME UPON RETIREMENT.
   In the event of termination with the Village for any reason, except for
disciplinary discharge, each Village employee who is entitled to a vacation
shall be paid on a lump sum basis for the balance of his or her entitled but
unused vacation time for the calendar year in which the employee retires. In
the event of the death of the employee, the foregoing lump sum payment shall be
paid to his or her lawfully designated beneficiary or his or her estate.
(Ord. 1993-37. Passed 3-10-93; Ord. 2017-83. Passed 12-13-17.)
254.11 COMPENSATION FOR ABSENCE DUE TO DEATH IN FAMILY.
   (a)   Each employee shall be entitled to be paid his or her regular rate of
compensation for an absence due to the death of a member of the employee's
immediate family. For the purpose of this section, members of an employee's
immediate family include only the employee's mother, father, sister, brother,
husband, wife, children (biological, adopted, or otherwise), mother-in-law,
father-in-law, grandchildren, grandparents and spouse's grandparents, or any
other person who clearly stands in the same relationship with the employee,
whether or not such persons live in the same residence as the employee.
   (b)   In the event that the funeral is 100 miles or less away from the
boundaries of the Village, the employee shall be compensated for no more than
three scheduled days or one scheduled tour of duty in the Fire Department. In
the event that the funeral is in excess of 100 miles away from the Village, the
employee shall be compensated for no more than five scheduled days or two
scheduled tours of duty in the Fire Department. The employee shall provide his
or her department head with a work release or equivalent from the funeral
director before compensation will be given.
   (c)   Any time off for funeral leave in excess of the time off as described
in this section may be charged to the employee's accumulated sick leave, but in
no event shall the total time off from work exceed two weeks of scheduled
working time.
   (d)   Permission to attend any funeral service for individuals not defined
herein may be requested by an employee to the department head, who may grant
such permission after approval by the employee’s department head. Department
heads seeking permission for such leave are required to obtain the approval of
the Mayor. The time off will be charged to the employee’s sick leave.
(Ord. 1996-58. Passed 4-10-96; Ord. 2017-83. Passed 12-13-17; Ord. 2024-26.
Passed 3- 13-24.)
254.12 HOLIDAYS AND PERSONAL DAYS.
   (a)   The employees named in subsections (e) and (f) hereof shall be allowed
additional pay, calculated on base pay, inclusive of longevity, during any
calendar year for either two personal days and/or the following twelve
holidays:
 
Presidents' Day Veterans' Day
Good Friday     Thanksgiving Day
Easter Sunday   The day after Thanksgiving
Memorial Day    Christmas Eve
Fourth of July  Christmas Day
Labor Day       New Year's Day
 
   The entitlement to either holidays or personal days shall be as specified in
subsection (e) or (f) hereof.
   (b)   The holidays and/or personal days to be taken by an employee shall be
determined by the head of the department in which the employee is employed. In
the event that any such employee, other than a member of the Police and Fire
Departments listed in paragraphs (e)(7) and (e)(8) hereof, is required to work
on any of the foregoing holidays or on personal days, he or she may be allowed
equivalent time off by his or her department head for each such holiday or
personal day that he or she is required to work. However, no more than three
such days off shall be added to the regular vacation period allowed to such
employee. If such employee listed in subsection (e) hereof is required to work
on any of the aforesaid holidays or personal days and is not given equivalent
time off, he or she shall be paid his or her base pay, inclusive of longevity,
for such holidays or personal days in addition to the holiday or personal day
pay provided for in this section.
   (c)   Members of the Police and Fire Department will be paid according to
the union contract.
   (d)   All non-bargaining full-time employees of the Village Hall, Building
Department, Finance Department, Police Department, Fire Department, Service
Department and Parks and Recreation Department, shall have the option to choose
either the time off from work on the Friday before or the Monday following a
weekend holiday or the holiday paid at the employee's overtime rate of pay.
   (e)   Except for those employees with a "Permanent Part-Time" designation,
holiday and personal day benefits shall not be paid to seasonal or part-time
employees (less than forty hours per week) who are paid on an hourly basis.

254.13 USE OF VILLAGE AUTOMOBILE BY MAYOR, POLICE CHIEF, FIRE CHIEF, AND POLICE
DETECTIVE.
   The Mayor, Police Chief, Fire Chief, and Police Detective shall be provided
with an automobile at Village expense and maintenance. Because the nature of
their positions requires such officers to be on call and available for Village
business twenty-four hours a day, such officers are authorized to use the
automobile in driving to and from their place of employment. Such officers are
further authorized to use the automobile in driving on miscellaneous minor
personal matters, as long as such officers reimburse the Village at the rate of
six hundred dollars ($600.00) per year in the month subsequent to the month in
which the vehicle was so utilized. The Chief Fiscal Officer is authorized to
enter into appropriate financial arrangements to carry out the provisions of
this section.

Passed 3-14-18; Ord. 2023-72. Passed 9-13-23.)
254.14 POLICY STATEMENT ON HARASSMENT IN THE WORKPLACE.
   (a)   The Village is committed to courteous and considerate treatment of its
employees at all times as an accepted standard of behavior. Consequently, the
Village is committed to a work atmosphere that is free of tension caused by
demeaning or harassing conduct, including animosity engendered by inappropriate
religious, racial or sexual conduct or comments.
   (b)   Equal employment opportunity laws identify two basic types of unlawful
sexual harassment:
      (1)   Where submission to unwelcome sexual advances and other physical or
verbal conduct is made a term or condition of an individual's employment, such
as demanding that a subordinate accept a date with a supervisor in order for
the subordinate to keep his or her job; and
      (2)   Where such conduct interferes with an individual's work performance
or creates an intimidating, hostile or offensive work environment.
   (c)   Sexual harassment is specifically prohibited by the Village's
policies. It is the obligation of each person to report any conduct which
violates these standards whether he or she is the victim or not, whether the
perpetrator is a supervisor, Councilmember, director, staff member or business
guest and regardless of the sex of the perpetrator.
   (d)   Any violation should be promptly reported to an employee's immediate
supervisor, to any supervisory person who the employee feels is the most
appropriate under the circumstances, or directly to the Mayor.
   (e)   The Village Law Director and /or Assistant Law Director will
immediately conduct a confidential investigation of any complaint, protecting
the identity of the complaining party, witnesses and the individual alleged to
have violated the policy, to the extent possible. A complaint made in good
faith assures that the complainant shall be protected from any retaliatory
action. Appropriate action will be taken if a violation of policy has occurred,
up to and including termination of employment, as determined by the Mayor and/
or Council.
(Res. 1994-150. Passed 12-14-94; Ord. 2017-83. Passed 12-13-17; Ord. 2018-32.
Passed 3-14-18.)
254.15 RETIREMENT INCENTIVE PLAN.
   (a)   Adoption of the Plan. There is hereby adopted a Retirement Incentive
Plan (“the Plan”) for all eligible employees of the Village of Cuyahoga Heights
who are members of the Public Employees Retirement System, which Plan provides
for the purchase by the Village of service credit for eligible employees who
elect to participate in the Plan and for payment by the Village of the entire
cost of the service credit purchase.
   (b)   Length of Plan. The Plan shall remain in effect for one year, from May
18, 2009 through May 18, 2010. The Plan may be extended beyond May 18, 2010 by
an action of Council. The Village shall give all eligible employees at least
thirty days' notice before termination of the Plan.
   (c)   One Plan. The Village shall have no more than one retirement incentive
plan for employees who are members of the Public Employees Retirement System in
effect at any time.
   (d)   Eligibility. Any employee of the Village who is a member of the Public
Employees Retirement System shall be eligible to participate in the Plan
established by the Village if he or she meets the following criteria:
      (1)   The employee is not any of the following:
         A.   An elected official, other than the full-time elected Mayor
serving a term beginning on or after January 1, 2026;
         B.   A member of a board or commission;
         C.   A person elected to serve a term of fixed length; or
         D.   A person appointed to serve a term of fixed length, other than a
person appointed and employed by the Village.
      (2)   The employee is or will be eligible to retire under Ohio R.C.
145.32, 145.33(A), 145.34 or 145.37 on or before the date of termination of the
Plan. Service credit to be purchased for the employee under the Plan shall be
included in making such determination.
      (3)   The employee agrees to retire under Ohio R.C. 145.32, 145.33(A),
145.34 or 145.37 within ninety days after receiving notice from the Public
Employees Retirement System that service credit has been purchased for him or
her under this section.
   Participation in the Plan shall be available to all eligible employees
without limit as to the number of employees who shall participate in the Plan
or the seniority of employees who shall participate in the Plan.
   (e)   Limits on Purchased Credit. The Plan shall purchase the same amount of
service credit for each participating employee, except that the Village will
not purchase more service credit for any employee than the lesser of the
following:
      (1)   Three years of service credit; or
      (2)   An amount of service credit equal to one-fifth of the total service
credited to the participant under Ohio R.C. 145.01 through 145.58, exclusive of
the service credit purchased under this section.
   For each year of service credit purchased under this section, the Village
shall pay an amount equal to the additional liability resulting from the
purchase of that year of service credit, as determined by an actuary employed
by the Public Employees Retirement Board.
   (f)   Agreed Upon Date for Payment. Upon the election by an eligible
employee to participate in the Plan, the employee and the Village shall agree
upon a date for payment or contracting for payment in installments, to the
Public Employees Retirement System, of the cost of the service credit to be
purchased. The Village shall submit to the Public Employees Retirement System a
written request for a determination of the cost of the service credit, and
within forty-five days after receiving the request the Public Employees
Retirement Board shall give the Village written notice of the cost.
   The Village shall pay or contract to pay in installments, to the Public
Employees Retirement System, the cost of the service credit to be purchased, on
the date agreed to by the employee and the Village. The payment shall be made
in accordance with the rules adopted by the Public Employees Retirement Board.
The rules may provide for payment in installments and for crediting the
purchased credit to the employee's account upon the Village's contracting to
pay the cost in installments. The Board shall notify the member when he or she
is credited with service purchased under this section. If the employee does not
retire within ninety days after receiving notice that he or she has been
credited with the purchase service credit, the Public Employees Retirement
System shall refund to the Village the amount paid for the service credit.
   No payment made to the Public Employees Retirement System under this section
shall affect any payment required by Ohio R.C. 145.48.
   (g)   Grievance Procedure. The following procedures will be in effect with
respect to grievances of any employee under the Plan:
      (1)   The Chief Fiscal Officer is hereby appointed as the designated
representative of the Village to receive grievances.
      (2)   Any eligible employee with a grievance shall state his or her
grievance in writing, in adequate detail, date it, and affix his or her
signature to the grievance.
      (3)   The Chief Fiscal Officer will attempt to resolve the grievance
within five days of its submission. If the Chief Fiscal Officer is unable to
resolve the grievance, he or she will then submit the grievance to the Mayor.
      (4)   If the Mayor is unable to resolve the grievance within ten days,
the grievance will then be submitted to Council, whose action in regard thereto
shall be final.
(Ord. 1987-57. Passed 7-22-87; Ord. 2001-32. Passed 4-11-01; Ord. 2001-72.
Passed 6-13-01; Ord. 2009-33. Passed 2-11-09; Ord. 2017-83. Passed 12-13-17;
Ord. 2018-32. Passed 3-14-18; Ord. 2025-14. Passed 2-12-25.)
254.151 RETIREMENT INCENTIVE PLAN - POLICE AND FIRE DEPARTMENTS.
   (a)   Adoption of the Plan. There is hereby adopted a Retirement Incentive
Plan (the “Plan”) for all eligible members of the Police and Fire Departments,
which plan provides for a payment to each eligible retiring member of the
Police and Fire Departments of one year base salary plus 10% of said base
salary conditioned upon the employee retiring during the time the Plan is in
place. The applicable base salary for purposes of the Retirement Incentive Plan
shall be the annual base salary in effect on the day the employee executes a
written agreement with the Village entering into the Retirement Incentive Plan.
   (b)   Length of Plan. The Plan shall remain in effect from February 10, 2009
through February 20, 2010, for all members of the Police and Fire Departments.
The Plan may be extended or renewed by an action of Council. The Village shall
give all eligible employees at least thirty days’ notice before termination of
the Plan.
   (c)   One Plan. The Village shall have no more than one Retirement Incentive
Plan for the Police and Fire Departments in effect at any time.
   (d)   Eligibility. Any member of the Police or Fire Department who is a
member of the Police and Fire Pension Fund pursuant to Ohio R.C. Chapter 742
and who is not a member of the Public Employees Retirement System, shall be
eligible to participate in the Plan established by the Village if he or she
meets the following criteria:
      (1)   The employee is not any of the following:
         A.   An elected official;
         B.   A member of a board or commission;
         C.   A person elected to serve a term of fixed length; or
         D.   A person appointed to serve a term of fixed length, other than a
person appointed and employed by the Village.
      (2)   The employee is or will be eligible to retire under Ohio R.C.
Chapter 742 on or before the date of termination of the Plan.
   (e)   Payment. The employee shall have one of the following options for
payments for the amounts due under the Plan:
      (1)   Initial payment of 50% of the amount due the employee at the time
of written commitment of retirement. The balance due the employee upon the day
of retirement.
      (2)   The entire amount due the employee under the Plan upon the date of
retirement. A written commitment of retirement would still be required.
      (3)   The entire amount due to the employee paid in equal annual
installments over a period of up to four years. The first installment shall be
paid to the employee on the date of retirement and each installment thereafter
shall be paid in the thirteenth pay period of each year following the year of
retirement. A written commitment of retirement would still be required.
   (f)   Administration of the Plan. The administration of the Plan shall be by
the Mayor and the Chief Fiscal Officer. They may develop administrative rules
to implement the Plan.
   (g)   Grievance Procedure. The following procedures will be in effect with
respect to grievances of any employee under the Plan:
      (1)   The Chief Fiscal Officer is hereby appointed as the designated
representative of the Village to receive grievances.
      (2)   Any eligible employee with a grievance shall state his or her
grievance in writing, in adequate detail, date it, and affix his or her
signature to the grievance.
      (3)   The Chief Fiscal Officer will attempt to resolve the grievance
within five days of its submission. If the Chief Fiscal Officer is unable to
resolve the grievance, he or she will then submit the grievance to the Mayor.
      (4)   If the Mayor is unable to resolve the grievance within ten days,
the grievance will then be submitted to Council, whose action in regard thereto
shall be final.
(Ord. 2001-33. Passed 4-11-01; Ord. 2009-33. Passed 2-11-09; Ord. 2009-57,
passed 4-8-09; Ord. 2009-72. Passed 5-13-09; Ord. 2009-73. Passed 5-13-09; Ord.
2009-119. Passed 8-12-09; Ord. 2017-83. Passed 12-13-17; Ord. 2018-32. Passed
3-14-18.)
254.16 EMPLOYEE PENSION CONTRIBUTION THROUGH SALARY AND COMPENSATION REDUCTION
PLAN.
   (a)   There is hereby authorized and adopted a plan under which the required
contributions of covered employees to the Ohio Police and Fire Pension Fund
(“Fund”), as defined in paragraph (f)(1) hereof, and to the Ohio Public
Employees Retirement System (“PERS”), as defined in paragraph (f)(2) hereof,
shall be made via employee salary or compensation reduction, to the extent not
otherwise paid by the Village under Sections
254.20 and
254.21 of the Village Code, respectively.
   (b)   The salary reduction plan is intended to comply with the requirements
of Section 414(h)(2) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 (the “Code”).
   (c)   The aforementioned salary reduction plan is mandatory. The amount of
said contributions paid to the Fund and to PERS by the Village via said salary
reduction plan shall be withheld from the gross compensation of each covered
employee. No covered employee shall have the option of choosing to receive the
contributed amounts directly instead of having them paid by the Village to the
Fund and to PERS.
   (d)   The Village specifically acknowledges that the contributions, although
designated as employee contributions for purposes of the Fund and PERS, are to
be paid by the Village in lieu of contributions by its covered employees.
   (e)   The Village shall pay to the Fund and to PERS the contributions
designated as employee contributions from the same source of funds as is used
in paying salaries.
   (f)   The salary reduction plan, adopted by the Village as provided in this
section, shall apply to the following covered employees:
      (1)   With respect to the Fund, all full-time police officers, as set
forth in Section
242.01, and all full-time members of the Fire Department, as set forth in
Section
244.01; and
      (2)   With respect to PERS, all employees of the Village who are required
to make contributions to PERS.
   (g)   The Chief Fiscal Officer is hereby directed to implement all
procedures necessary in the administration of the pay of all persons described
in subsection (f) hereof to effect the salary reduction plan, as of the
effective date of this section, of a portion of the statutorily required
contributions to the Fund and of all of the statutorily required contributions
to the Fund and of all of the statutorily required contributions to PERS so as
to enable the aforementioned covered employees to obtain the resulting Federal
and Ohio tax deferments and other attendant benefits.
   (h)   The Chief Fiscal Officer is hereby directed to obtain the approval of
the Fund and PERS regarding the Village's implementation of the salary
reduction plan and to implement all administrative procedures required by the
Fund and PERS.
   (i)   The salary reduction pick-up plan as herein set forth may be amended
from time to time to satisfy any additional requirements which may arise as a
result of any future amendment to Section 414(h)(2) of the Code.
   (j)   The portion of the covered employees' mandatory contributions to be
made, via salary reduction, by the Village, may be changed from time to time by
legislation adopted by Council.
(Ord. 1990-74. Passed 6-27-90; Ord. 2013-92. Passed 10-9-13; Ord. 2017-83.
Passed 12-13-17.)

254.18 FRINGE BENEFIT PICK-UP PLAN - POLICE AND FIRE PENSION FUND.
   (a)   There is hereby authorized and adopted a pick-up plan under which the
Village shall pick up four and one-half percent of the contributions of the
covered employees to the Police and Fire Pension Fund of Ohio (the “Fund”).
   (b)   The pick-up plan is intended to comply with the requirements of
Section 414(h)(2) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, as amended.
   (c)   The aforementioned pick-up is mandatory and no covered employee shall
have the option of choosing to receive the contributed amounts directly instead
of having them paid by the Village to the Fund.
   (d)   The Village specifically acknowledges that the contributions, although
designated as employee contributions for purposes of the Fund, are to be paid
by the Village in lieu of contributions by its covered employees.
   (e)   The Village shall pay to the Fund the contributions designated as
employee contributions from the same source of funds as used in paying
salaries.
   (f)   The pick-up by the Village, as provided for in this section, shall
apply to the following covered employees:
      (1)   All full-time police officers, as set forth in Section
242.01; and
      (2)   All full-time members of the Fire Department as set forth in
Section
244.01.
   (g)   The Chief Fiscal Officer is hereby directed, as of the effective date
of this section, to implement all procedures necessary in the administration of
the pay of all persons described in subsection (f) hereof to effect the pick-up
of a portion of the statutorily required contributions to the Fund so as to
enable the aforementioned covered employees to obtain the resulting Federal and
Ohio tax deferments and other attendant benefits.
   (h)   The pick-up plan as hereinbefore set forth may be amended from time to
time to satisfy any additional requirements which may arise as a result of any
future amendment to Section 414(h)(2) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, as
amended.
   (i)   The portion of the covered employees' mandatory contributions to be
picked- up by the Village may be changed from time to time by legislation
adopted by Council.
(Ord. 2017-83. Passed 12-13-17.)
254.19 FRINGE BENEFIT PICK-UP PLAN - PUBLIC EMPLOYEES RETIREMENT SYSTEM (PERS).
   (a)   There is hereby authorized and adopted a pick-up plan under which the
Village shall pick up four and one-half percent of the contributions of the
covered employees (excluding elected officials and certain part-time employees)
to the Public Employees Retirement System of Ohio (PERS).
   (b)   The pick-up plan is intended to comply with the requirements of
Section 414(h)(2) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, as amended.
   (c)   The aforementioned pick-up is mandatory and no covered employee shall
have the option of choosing to receive the contributed amounts directly instead
of having them paid by the Village to PERS.
   (d)   The Village specifically acknowledges that the contributions, although
designated as employee contributions for purposes of PERS, are to be paid by
the Village in lieu of contributions by its covered employees.
   (e)   The Village shall pay to PERS the contributions designated as employee
contributions from the same source of funds as used in paying salaries.
   (f)   The pick-up by the Village, as provided for in this section, shall
apply to the following covered employees: all full-time PERS employees, and
including the full-time elected Mayor serving any term beginning after January
1, 2026, but excluding all other Village officials.
   (g)   The Chief Fiscal Officer is hereby directed, as of the effective date
of this section, to implement all procedures necessary in the administration of
the pay of all persons described in subsection (f) hereof to effect the pick up
of a portion of the statutorily required contributions to PERS so as to enable
the aforementioned covered employees to obtain the resulting Federal and Ohio
tax deferments and other attendant benefits.
   (h)   The pick-up plan as hereinbefore set forth may be amended from time to
time to satisfy any additional requirements which may arise as a result of any
future amendment to Section 414(h)(2) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, as
amended.
   (i)   The portion of the covered employees' mandatory contributions to be
picked up by the Village may be changed from time to time by legislation
adopted by Council.
   (j)   Pursuant to the authority of Section 254.21(i), the portion of the
covered employees' mandatory contribution to be picked up, via salary
reduction, by the Village (specifically payments of PERS contributions) for the
following employees shall be suspended from July 26, 2009 to July 25, 2010:
Service Department mechanic, foremen, laborers and bus driver; Administrative
Assistant to the Chief and Police Services; Administrative Assistant to the
Mayor; Administrative Accounting Assistant, and Chief Fiscal Officer.
(Res. 2000-61. Passed 4-26-00; Ord. 2009-104. Passed 7-8-09; Ord. 2010-71.

254.20 PART-TIME EMPLOYEES.
   (a)   Notwithstanding any other provisions in these Codified Ordinances, any
part-time worker hired in any department of the Village shall receive no
benefits and shall be paid only an hourly wage.
   (b)   Effective January 1, 2020 and every January 1st thereafter any part
time employee who works for the Village in various capacities on a "year round"
basis shall be designated as a permanent part time employee and receive paid
time off as set forth in this section including: vacation; forty annual sick
leave hours; and all Village paid holidays. By way of illustration, a service
department permanent part time employee who works twenty-eight hours per week
year round after one year of continual employment shall receive six days of
vacation, forty hours of sick leave, and twelve paid holidays. No vacation or
sick time is to be carried over from year to year.
   (c)   In order to be designated as a permanent part-timer and be eligible
for benefits under this section, the employee must work fewer than an average
of forty hours per week and average more than twenty-eight hours per week, but
must be continuously employed by the Village on a part-time basis throughout
the calendar year. Employees on military duty or extended sick time may be
still considered for permanent part time designation. An employee must work a
full calendar year on a permanent part-time basis before becoming eligible for
paid time off and holiday. Only the Mayor may designate an employee as
"permanent part-time employee."
   Permanent Part-Time Designation Vacation Schedule
 
Years of Service                                          Length of Vacation
Start of 2nd year through 5 completed calendar years      6 working days
Start of 6th year through 10 completed calendar years and 10 working days
onward
 
Vacation and holidays are calculated on the average hours worked in a scheduled
work day. This will be calculated based on average from the previous calendar
year.
(Ord. 2005-78. Passed 5-11-05; Ord. 2017-83. Passed 12-13-17; Ord. 2020-06.
Passed 1- 8-2020; Ord. 2024-73. Passed 12-11-24.)

   (a)   The Village Hall staff shall be permitted to wear uniforms for their

   (b)   The Village Hall staff has an allowance each year, if needed, for not

   Clothing allowance not to exceed five hundred dollar ($500.00) limit in one
year.
(Ord. 2014-26. Passed 2-12-14; Ord. 2017-83. Passed 12-13-17.)
   254.22 FRAUD REPORTING.
   (a)   Ohio R.C. 117.103 creates the Auditor of State's system for reporting
fraud, including misuse and misappropriation of public money, by any public
office or public official. The system allows Ohio residents and any employee of
the Village to make anonymous complaints through a toll-free number, the
Auditor of State's website, or the United States mail, to the Auditor of
State's office.
   (b)   Village employees may report fraud: (i) by calling 1-866-Fraud-OH;
(ii) by e-mailing a complaint to fraudohio@ohioauditor.gov; (iii) or by mailing
a complaint to 88 East Broad St., P.O. Box 1140, Columbus, OH 43215. Additional
information, including a form for reporting fraud to the Auditor of State can
be found on the Auditor's website at https://ohioauditor.gov/fraud.html.
   (c)   The Village shall provide information about the Ohio fraud-reporting
system and the means of reporting fraud to each new employee by providing each
new employee with this information, and the Village shall require each new
employee to sign an Acknowledgment of Receipt of the fraud reporting
information contained therein, which acknowledgment shall be given/obtained
within 30 days of the date of hire for any new employee.
   (d)   Existing employees shall receive a copy of this notification upon its
enactment, and shall sign an acknowledgment of receipt of same.
(Ord. 2015-13. Passed 2-11-15; Ord. 2017-83. Passed 12-13-17.)
CHAPTER 256
Compensation
EDITOR'S NOTE: Because of the frequency of change, provisions relating to
regular compensation of union contracts are not codified. Schedules of the same
are established from time to time by Council and copies thereof may be
obtained, at cost, from the Clerk of Council.
Resolution 1988-14, passed February 10, 1988, authorized an agreement with The
Delaware Group for administration of a deferred compensation program for
employees of the Village pursuant to Section 457 of the Internal Revenue Code.
Copies of this agreement and the latest relevant legislation may be obtained,
at cost, from the Clerk of Council.

256.02   Rate of pay for new hires. (Repealed)
256.03   Overtime compensation for Police and Fire Departments.
256.04   Overtime compensation for certain other employees.
256.05   Defining "time worked" for the purpose of calculating overtime.
256.06   Longevity pay.
256.07   Compensatory time off for certain other employees.

256.01 COMPENSATION SCHEDULE.
   Village Council, through ordinance, shall set the compensation schedule for
Village elected officials, officers, and employees. Said compensation shall be
reflected either as a set figure or, for Village employees only, as a range. If
the compensation is set by a range, the Mayor may, in his discretion, set the
compensation within the range for each employee holding that position. Prior to
any change in the range by the Mayor, Council shall be notified forthwith.
(Ord. 2000-58. Passed 4-12-00; Ord. 2005-100. Passed 6-8-05; Ord. 2006-52.
Passed 3-8-06; Ord. 2006-97. Passed 6-7-06; Ord. 2006-101. Passed 6-7-06; Ord.

256.02 RATE OF PAY FOR NEW HIRES. (REPEALED)
   (EDITOR’S NOTE: Section 256.02 was repealed by Ordinance 2013-08, passed
February 13, 2013.)
256.03 OVERTIME COMPENSATION FOR POLICE AND FIRE DEPARTMENTS.
   All police officers and firefighters, including cadets, but excluding the
Police Chief, Deputy Police Chief, the Fire Chief, and the Assistant Fire
Chief, shall receive overtime at the rate of one and a half times their hourly
rate of pay for time worked in excess of 40 hours per week for the Police
Department and in excess of the hours prescribed in Section
244.02 for the Fire Department. This rate shall be deemed the regular hourly
rate as such term is used in the Fair Labor Standards Act.
(Ord. 1996-43. Passed 3-27-96; Ord. 2008-118. Passed 6-11-08; Ord. 2009-179.
Passed 12-9-09; Ord. 2010-30. Passed 3-10-10; Ord. 2010-32. Passed 3-10-10;
Ord. 2013-18. Passed 2-13-13; Ord. 2018-32. Passed 3-14-18.)
256.04 OVERTIME COMPENSATION FOR CERTAIN OTHER EMPLOYEES.
   (a)   The non-bargaining, full-time employees of the Village Hall, Building
Department, Finance Department, Police Department, Fire Department, Service
Department and Parks and Recreation Department, (except the Chief Fiscal
Officer, Building Commissioner, Police Chief, Deputy Chief, Fire Chief,
Assistant Fire Chief, Service Director, Assistant Service Director and Parks
and Recreation Director), shall be compensated for time worked in excess of 40
hours per weekly pay period at the rate of one and one-half times their
established rate of compensation. This rate shall be deemed the regular hourly
rate as such term is used in the "Fair Labor Standards Act."
   (b)   The rate of pay for full-time members of the Service Department,
excluding the Service Director and Assistant Service Director, for actual time
worked on the holidays of Thanksgiving, Christmas and New Year's Day, shall be
double time and a half, in addition to the regular pay for the actual holiday.
If any of the above holidays fall on a weekend, the regular holiday pay will be
paid in overtime, provided the employee worked in excess of 40 hours during the
week.
(Ord. 1996-49. Passed 4-10-96; Ord. 1999-26. Passed 2-10-99; Ord. 2008-118.
Passed 6-11-08; Ord. 2009-23. Passed 1-14-09; Ord. 2010-43. Passed 4-14-10;
Ord. 2012-65. Passed 7-11-12; Ord. 2014-9. Passed 1-8-14; Ord. 2025-13. Passed
2-12-25.)
256.05 DEFINING "TIME WORKED" FOR THE PURPOSE OF CALCULATING OVERTIME.
   (a)   "Time worked", for the purpose of calculating overtime compensation
for Village employees, shall include the following activities which occur
during a seven-day work week:
      (1)   Vacation time;
      (2)   Holiday time;
      (3)   Personal days;
      (4)   A job-incurred injury (time off when the injury occurs);
      (5)   Leave due to death in the employee's immediate family, according to
the provisions of Section
254.11;
      (6)   A court appearance on behalf of the Village;
      (7)   Attendance at a job-related school when required by a prior written
order of the department head;
      (8)   Mandatory training time;
      (9)   Emergency call-out;
      (10)   Stand-by duty; and
      (11)   Compensatory time off pursuant to Section
256.07 for members of the Police and Fire Departments and certain other
employees when requested by the employee one week in advance and with the prior
written approval of the department head.
   (b)   "Time worked", for the purpose of calculating overtime for Village
employees, shall not include the following activities which occur during a
seven-day work week:
      (1)   Personal sick time;
      (2)   Duty-related sick time (for time off which is related to an injury
which previously occurred); and
      (3)   Jury duty.
(Ord. 2000-30. Passed 4-12-00.)
256.06 LONGEVITY PAY.
   The longevity pay which is included in the compensation schedule as
established from time to time by Council, for the full-time Village employees,
shall be calculated according to the following schedule and will be payable
biweekly or semimonthly, based upon continuous employment by the Village:
   (a)   (1)   All full-time Village employees hired prior to June 1, 2006 who
regularly work no less than forty hours per week:
         Years of Service   Per Year
         Four or more       $ +1,100.00
         Six or more      +300.00
         Eight or more   +300.00
         Ten or more      +300.00
         Twelve or more   +300.00
         Fourteen or more   +300.00
         Sixteen or more   +300.00
         Eighteen or more   +300.00
         Twenty or more   +300.00
         Twenty-two or more   +300.00
         Twenty-four or more    +300.00
                  $4,100.00
      (2)   All full-time Village employees hired on or after June 1, 2006, who
regularly work no less than forty hours per week:
         Years of Service    Per Year
         Four or more      $500.00
         Nine or more      $1,000.00
         Fourteen or more   $1,500.00
         Eighteen or more   $1,900.00
         Twenty-two or more   $2,300.00
         Twenty-four or more   $2,600.00
   (b)   Part-time Clerk/Dispatchers hired after May 1, 2005 who work no less
than thirty-two hours per week (1,664 hours per year):
         Years of Service         Per Year
         Four or more            $+880.00
         Six or more             +240.00
         Eight or more          +240.00
         Ten or more             +240.00
         Twelve or more          +240.00
         Fourteen or more          +240.00
         Sixteen or more          +240.00
         Eighteen or more          +240.00
         Twenty or more          +240.00
         Twenty-two or more           +240.00
         Twenty-four or more       +240.00
                        $3,280.00
   (c)   All full-time employees eligible for a longevity increase shall
receive their longevity increase beginning on the first full pay period of
January of the calendar year in which the vesting anniversary date occurs,
instead of on the employee's actual anniversary date, and shall be
incrementally reflected in each pay period of that calendar year. Upon
termination of employment, except lay off or duty-related disability, any
longevity paid to the employee to which the employee was not entitled, as a
result of the termination of employment occurring prior to the vesting
anniversary date, will be deducted from the employee's last pay.
(Ord. 1998-19. Passed 1-14-98; Ord. 1998-105. Passed 8-19-98; Ord. 1998-140.
Passed 11-9-98; Ord. 2001-32. Passed 4-11-01; Ord. 2005-79. Passed 5-11-05;
Ord. 2006-96. Passed 6-7-06; Ord. 2009-145. Passed 10-14-09; Ord. 2009-175.
Passed 12-9-09; Ord. 2015-14. Passed 2-11-15.)
256.07 COMPENSATORY TIME OFF FOR CERTAIN OTHER EMPLOYEES.
   The non-bargaining full-time hourly employees of the Village (except
salaried and/or exempt employees), may request compensatory time off in lieu of
overtime worked from the respective heads of their departments, subject to the
following terms and conditions:
   (a)   The total cumulative compensatory time off logged for each employee
shall not exceed 160 hours, at any one time, from January 1 to the last pay
period of the then current year. The Fiscal Office shall keep an account of
each employee's total compensatory time accumulated and compensatory time used.
   (b)   When an employee requests compensatory time off from the department
head in lieu of overtime worked (the time is equal to time and one-half (1.5),
the time worked may not be credited to compensatory time off during the same
pay period as it was earned.
   (c)   The compensatory time that is accumulated may be used by the employee
at any time during the year upon the prior approval of the department head. The
time must be scheduled so that it will not cost the Village overtime for the
services of other employees.
   (d)   At year's end, an employee may roll over up to 60 hours to the
succeeding year, but must be paid at his or her regular rate of pay for all
hours accumulated in excess of 60 hours. An employee may also cash-in up to 60
hours of compensatory time once during the calendar year with a written request
provided to the employer in the pay period prior to the pay period the cash-in
is desired.
(Ord. 2000-56. Passed 4-12-00; Ord. 2003-131. Passed 10-8-03; Ord. 2005-79.
Passed 5-11-05; Ord. 2005-101. Passed 6-8-05; Ord. 2008-119. Passed 6-11-08;
Ord. 2009-179. Passed 12-9-09; Ord. 2010-30. Passed 3-10-10; Ord. 2010-32.
Passed 3-10-10; Ord. 2010-43. Passed 4-14-10; Ord. 2010-71. Passed 7-14-10;
Ord. 2013-18. Passed 2-13-13; Ord. 2017-09. Passed 2-8-17; Ord. 2018-32. Passed
3-14-18; Ord. 2025- 13. Passed 2-12-25; Ord. 2025-49. Passed 8-13-25.)
256.08 PURCHASE OF LIFE INSURANCE.
   For all full-time employees, including full-time elected officials and part
time Clerk/Dispatchers hired prior to May 11, 2005, the Village shall purchase
and the Chief Fiscal Officer shall be authorized to pay for a policy of term
life insurance in the amount of twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000). The
purchase of the insurance shall be subject to review by Council on an annual
basis, to determine whether the purchase should be continued, the level of
insurance and the cost thereof.
(Ord. 2002-118. Passed 9-11-02; Ord. 2003-132. Passed 10-8-03; Ord. 2005-79.
Passed 5-11-05; Ord. 2009-36. Passed 2-11-09; Ord. 2018-32. Passed 3-14-18.)
256.09 COFFEE, MEALS, ETC.
   The Chief Fiscal Officer, upon proper appropriation, is authorized to pay
for coffee, meals, refreshments and other amenities which are considered fringe
benefits for municipal officers and employees of the Village.
(Ord. 2003-164. Passed 12-10-03; Ord. 2019-34. Passed 5-8-19.)
256.10   PHYSICAL FITNESS INCENTIVE.
   (a)   Full-time non-bargaining unit Village employees shall be eligible to
receive a supplemental pay allowance on the following basis:
      (1)   On a voluntary basis, once per calendar year, a full-time non-
bargaining unit Village employee may choose to become eligible for an annual
physical fitness allowance (PFT) in the amount of five hundred dollars
($500.00). In order to become eligible for this allowance, the employee must
sign a waiver, which shall indemnify and hold the Village, and its agents and
employees, harmless against any claim, demand, suit on liability (monetary or
otherwise) in connection with an employee's efforts to qualify for such
allowance.
      (2)   Any employee may qualify for the full supplemental pay allowance by
passing all minimum fitness incentive standards for a one-mile run, a series of
push-ups, and a series of sit-ups. The minimum standards are both age and
gender specific as set forth below. Successful completion of 100 percent of all
minimum standards shall receive the allowance as set forth above. Successful
completion of seventy-five percent of all minimum standards in each and every
category will receive seventy-five percent of the allowance set forth above.
Successful completion of fifty percent of all minimum standards in each and
every category will receive fifty percent of the allowance set forth above.
Failure to reach at least fifty percent of the minimum standard in all
categories will result in the employee being ineligible to receive any portion
of the above allowance.
         Tri-C’s OPOTC instructors will conduct the physical fitness assessment
as per the following standards:
Minimum Standards for Males
Event/Age Group        17-21 22-26 27-31 32-36 37-41 42-46 47-51 52-58 57+
Push-ups (# reps)      42    40    39    36    34    30    25    20    18
75%                    32    30    30    27    26    23    19    15    14
50%                    21    20    20    18    17    15    13    10    9

75%                    15    13    13    12    10    9     8     7     6
50%                    10    9     9     8     7     6     5     5     4
Sit-ups (# reps)       53    50    45    42    38    32    30    28    27
75%                    40    38    34    32    29    24    23    21    21
50%                    27    25    23    21    19    16    15    14    14
One mile run (minutes) 9:27  9:48  10:15 10:51 11:21 11:51 12:00 12:12 12:24
