1062.01 RECREATION MANAGER; COMPENSATION; RESPONSIBILITIES.
   The Village swimming pool shall be under the management of the Recreation
Manager. He or she shall be responsible for the operation of the pool and the
promulgation and enforcement of rules and regulations pertaining to its use.
(Ord. 1994-69. Passed 4-27-94; Ord. 2012-85. Passed 9-12-12; Ord. 2018-86.
Passed 10-10-18.)
1062.02 POOL PERSONNEL; COMPENSATION.
   The Recreation Manager shall have authority to appoint personnel for the
proper operation of the pool and such personnel shall be paid at the rates
established from time to time by Council. No pool personnel shall be appointed
who is a current user of illegal drugs; who has been convicted of a felony; who
has been guilty of infamous or notoriously disgraceful conduct; who has been
dismissed from any public position for delinquency or misconduct; or who has
made false statements of any material fact or has practiced, or attempted to
practice, any deception or fraud in the applicant’s application or examination
in establishing the applicant’s ability or in securing said appointment.
(Ord. 1994-69. Passed 4-27-94; Ord. 2009-163. Passed 11-11-09; Ord. 2012-85.
Passed 9-12-12; Ord. 2018-86. Passed 10-10-18.)
1062.03 ADMISSION.
   Admission to the swimming pool and its facilities shall be limited to pool
pass holders and their minor children and guests when accompanied by a pass
holder. Bona fide residents of the Village and of the Cuyahoga Heights School
District shall be eligible to receive a swimming pool season pass. A swimming
pool pass must be shown to the cashier upon each entry into the facility.
(Ord. 1994-69. Passed 4-27-94; Ord. 2012-85. Passed 9-12-12.)
1062.04 SEASON PASSES; FEES.
   (a)   Swimming pool season passes shall be issued annually by the Village
Clerk or Mayor to all applicants who are a resident of the Village or a
resident of the Cuyahoga Heights School District, and their minor children over
two years old, upon presentation of satisfactory proof of residence.
   The Village Clerk and the Mayor shall also have authority to issue special
nonresident swimming pool season passes in such number as will not result in
overcrowding of the pool and yet allow its full use.
(Ord. 1994-69. Passed 4-27-94.)
   (b)   Fees to be charged for a swimming pool season pass shall be as
established from time to time by Council. However, the Mayor, or his designee,
may issue and set the fees for daily pool passes and for group special events,
such as swimming pool parties.
(Ord. 2012-85. Passed 9-12-12.)
1062.05 POOL HOURS OF OPERATION AND SEASON.
   The Mayor shall determine the dates upon which the swimming pool and
facilities open and close for the season and the daily hours in which the
swimming pool and facilities are open for use. The Mayor shall also have the
authority to set policies regarding use of the swimming pool and facilities.
(Ord. 1994-69. Passed 4-27-94; Ord. 2012-85. Passed 9-12-12.)

CHAPTER 1066
Klima Gardens
1066.01   Designation of Gardens as Village recreational area; usage.
1066.02   Rules and regulations; deposit; fee.
   CROSS REFERENCES

755.12 et seq.
   Recreation Commission - see ADM.

   Desecration - see GEN. OFF.

   Criminal damaging or endangering - see GEN. OFF.

   Criminal mischief - see GEN. OFF.

Ch. 1076
1066.01 DESIGNATION OF GARDENS AS VILLAGE RECREATIONAL AREA; USAGE.
   The Village property known as "Klima Gardens at Chapek Grove," situated at
4646 East 71st Street, shall be used primarily as a recreational area for the
residents of the Village. Other groups or organizations may use Klima Gardens
("the property") only under the terms prescribed in this chapter.
(Ord. 2002-153. Passed 11-13-02.)
1066.02 RULES AND REGULATIONS; DEPOSIT; FEE.
   The following rules and regulations shall apply to the use of the property:
   (a)   Any person desiring to use the property shall obtain a permit from the
Mayor according to the procedure set forth by his or her office. Bona fide
Cuyahoga Heights residents may reserve one date, beginning the first working
day of January; Village governmental nonresident employees and businesses
located in the Village may book one date beginning February 1; and outside
businesses and other nonresidents may book one date beginning March 1 of each
calendar year. Any applicant who desires a second date may reserve another date
beginning March 1 of the calendar year.
   (b)   The applicant shall pay a nonrefundable deposit of four hundred
dollars ($400.00) to be excused from the requirement to clean the property to
its original condition after use. If there is any damage to the property caused
by the applicant or their guests, except normal wear and tear, the renter shall
not be eligible to rent any Village facilities for a minimum of one year
following the event.
   (c)   The fee for the use of the property shall be one thousand dollars
($1,000.00) per day, which shall be deposited by the CFO into the General Fund.
The fee shall not be charged if the applicant is a Village resident or
organization located in Cuyahoga Heights using the property for a private
party. Village residents who request to use Klima Gardens for an outside
organization shall pay the fee. Organizations within a business located in the
Village, such as a union or credit union, shall not be exempted from this fee.
Non-profit organizations or senior citizen groups may be charged at the rate of
four hundred dollars ($400.00).
   (d)   The property shall not be used later than 12:00 midnight and the
clean-up of the area shall be completed by that time.
   (e)   No alcoholic beverages shall be sold unless strictly in accordance
with a license issued by the Ohio Department of Commerce, Division of Liquor
Control. A uniformed Cuyahoga Heights police officer shall be required to be
present at all functions where a state liquor license is required, and at all
weddings and/or wedding receptions. The cost of the police officer shall be
paid for by the applicant. Applicants should contact the Cuyahoga Heights Chief
of Police (at 216-640-2045) to secure a police officer for an event.
   (f)   All guests, including children and caterers, are the responsibility of
the applicant. Thefts from the property will be prosecuted. All liquor law
responsibility shall be incurred by the applicant.
   (g)   If the applicant is going to use a "hot oil fryer" at an event, he or
she must obtain a permit from the member of the Village Fire Department who is
performing the duties of the Village Fire Inspector to have the fryer on the
premises prior to the day of the event. Applicants should contact the Village
Fire Department (at 216- 641-6799) at least five business days prior to the
event to obtain a permit.
   (h)   The Village is not responsible to provide phone lines, internet, and/
or cable for any individual or entity renting Klima Gardens.
   (i)   Additional rules regarding use of the property shall be promulgated by
the Mayor. Failure of any person using the property to comply with any rule set
forth in this section, or any rule promulgated by the Mayor, pursuant to this
division, shall be cause not to be eligible to rent Klima Gardens in the
future. In addition, any resident found to be renting the property for an
outside organization shall be denied rental privileges in the following
calendar year.
      (Ord. 2002-153. Passed 11-13-02; Ord. 2004-76. Passed 5-12-04; Ord. 2009-
54. Passed 4-8-09; Ord. 2010-59. Passed 6-9-10; Ord. 2013-47. Passed 5-8-13;
Ord. 2022-94. Passed 12-14-22.)
CHAPTER 1068
Village Hall
1068.01   Management by Mayor and Council.
1068.02   Employment of additional help.
1068.03   Rules and regulations applicable to use of Auditorium and Civic
Center.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Council generally - see ADM.
Ch. 220
   Smoking in Village buildings - see ADM. 220.07
   Mayor generally - see ADM.
Ch. 230
   Criminal damaging or endangering - see GEN. OFF.

   Congregating on Municipal property - see GEN. OFF.
648.11
   Theft of rented property - see GEN. OFF.
672.045,
672.14
1068.01 MANAGEMENT BY MAYOR AND COUNCIL.
   The Mayor shall be ex officio manager of the Village Hall and as such shall
supervise its maintenance and operation, subject only to the authority of
Council with respect thereto.
(1986 Code § 957.01)
1068.02 EMPLOYMENT OF ADDITIONAL HELP.
   In the event that it should be necessary from time to time to employ
additional help in connection with the maintenance and operation of the Village
Hall, such help shall be employed by the Mayor. The employment of any such
help, and the period of the employment, shall be certified to the Clerk by the
Mayor.
(1986 Code § 957.03)
1068.03 RULES AND REGULATIONS APPLICABLE TO USE OF AUDITORIUM AND CIVIC CENTER.
   The following rules and regulations shall apply to the use of the Auditorium
in the Village Hall:
   (a)   Any Village resident or nonresident Village governmental employee over
21 years of age or any Village business or Village organization desiring to use
the Auditorium in the Village Hall shall apply at the office of the Mayor. The
applicant using the Auditorium must be present at the event. No resident or
nonresident employee may book the Auditorium for other nonresidents or outside
organizations.
   (b)   The applicant shall pay a nonrefundable deposit of two hundred dollars
($200.00) to be excused from the requirement to clean the Auditorium to its
original condition after use. If there is any damage to the property caused by
the applicant or their guests, except normal wear and tear, the applicant shall
not be eligible to rent any Village facilities for a minimum of one year
following the event.
   (c)   A business within the Village may rent the Auditorium for meetings of
that business only, on Mondays through Fridays; no deposit shall be required.
The Village of Cuyahoga Heights' organizations and/or committees, including,
but not limited to, the Senior Citizens Group, Recreation Board, Youth
Committee Historical Committee, Boy Scouts and/or Girl Scouts that meet weekly
or biweekly shall not be required to make a deposit.
   (d)   Each Village residential household or Village government employee
household may rent the Auditorium for their own personal use three times in
each calendar year.
   (e)   The Auditorium shall not be used for any one party longer than eight
(8) hours which shall include set-up and clean-up times and under no
circumstances shall be used later than midnight. The clean-up of the Auditorium
shall be completed by the exit time listed on the application.
   (f)   No smoking or alcoholic beverages shall be permitted anywhere in the
Village Hall. No weddings, bachelor parties, gambling, reverse raffles, night
at the races or live music shall be permitted. The use of a "hot oil fryer" and
any type of a "fog/smoke" machine is prohibited from use anywhere in the
Village Hall. No decorations may be taped onto walls and/or woodwork within the
Village Hall; decorations should be limited to tables. Village-sponsored bingo
shall be permitted. Approval of other types of activities shall be at the
discretion of the Mayor.
   (g)   A deejay shall be permitted at the applicant's party.
   (h)   The rental of the Auditorium shall be limited to the individual
facility. No person shall be permitted in any other room or on any other floor
of the Village Hall other than that which was rented. Children must be under
full adult supervision at all times and shall not play on the elevator or the
stage area.
   (i)   Additional rules regarding use of the Auditorium shall be promulgated
by the Mayor. Failure of any person renting the Auditorium to comply with any
rule set forth in this section or any rule promulgated by the Mayor pursuant to
this division shall be cause not to be eligible to rent the Auditorium in the
future. In addition, any resident found to be renting the Auditorium for a
nonresident or outside organization shall be denied rental privileges in the
following calendar year.
      (Ord. 1996-155. Passed 11-13-96; Ord. 1997-119. Passed 9-10-97; Ord.
2002-152. Passed 11-13-02; Ord. 2005-43. Passed 3-9-05; Ord. 2009-55. Passed 4-
8-09; Ord. 2022-94. Passed 12-14-22.)

1070.01 AUTHORITY OF SERVICE DEPARTMENT; CONDITIONS.
   The Service Department, upon terms stated herein, and under such other rules
and regulations as may be established by the Mayor, consistent herewith and
necessary in order to carry out the provisions of this chapter, shall provide
snow removal services to all qualified residents of the Village, as stated

equipment are available, after all necessary public highway, street and
sidewalk snow removal is accomplished or provided for, and subject to the
following terms:

and
   (b)   The residents (and the property owner if the eligible resident is not
the sole owner) shall execute a consent and release in a form approved by the
Solicitor, granting permission to the Village to provide such snow removal
service and exonerating the Village from any and all liability in connection
with the provision of such service.

CHAPTER 1072
Grass Cutting for Resident Senior Citizens and Disabled Persons
1072.01   Conditions of service.
1072.02   Registration; fee.
1072.03   Rules and regulations; authority of Service Director.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Ohio Department of Aging - see Ohio R.C. 173.01 et seq.
   Municipal services and facilities for senior citizens - see Ohio R.C.
717.01, 5705.19
   Driving upon tree lawns - see TRAF.

   Injuring vegetation - see GEN. OFF.

   Maintenance of trees, grass and shrubbery in yard areas - see B. & H.

1072.01 CONDITIONS OF SERVICE.
   A grass cutting service for resident senior citizens and resident disabled
persons of the Village shall be provided under the following conditions:
   (a)   (1)   The registrant must be 60 years of age or older and must reside
alone or with a spouse of like age or older, or the registrant must be disabled
and not have an able-bodied person living with him or her who is under 60 years
of age.
      (2)   For purposes of this division (a), “disabled” means that a federal
or state agency responsible for providing benefits to disabled persons (for
example, the Social Security Administration, the Centers for Medicare and
Medicaid Services, or the State of Ohio Department of Medicaid) has found and
determined that a person is currently disabled and entitled to receive benefits
from that agency.
   (b)   The property registered pursuant to Section
1072.02 must be a single-family dwelling, a two-family dwelling, or a multiple-
family dwelling, and the owner of the property must reside at the registered
property.
   (c)   The registrant must execute a consent and release, in a form approved
by the Solicitor, granting permission to the Village to provide the grass
cutting service and releasing the Village, its servants, agents and employees,
from any liability arising out of the cutting of grass on the registrant’s
property.
      (Ord. 1996-66. Passed 4-24-96; Ord. 2008-87. Passed 5-14-08; Ord. 2023-
20. Passed 3-8-23.)
1072.02 REGISTRATION; FEE.
   Each eligible registrant for the service shall register with the Village by
completing the consent and release referred to in Section
1072.01(d), in a manner and form approved by the Mayor. There shall be no
annual registration fee for this service.
(Ord. 1996-66. Passed 4-24-96.)
1072.03 RULES AND REGULATIONS; AUTHORITY OF SERVICE DIRECTOR.
   The Service Director may make such reasonable rules and regulations,
consistent with the intent of this chapter, as are necessary to provide the
service to eligible residents.
(Ord. 1996-66. Passed 4-24-96.)
CHAPTER 1074
Recovery of Costs of Emergency Actions
1074.01   Purpose.
1074.02   Definitions.
1074.03   Liability.
1074.04   Services of other governmental bodies or parties.
1074.05   Procedure.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Hazardous and solid wastes - see Ohio R.C. 3734.01 et seq.
   Environmental Protection Agency - see Ohio R.C. 3745.01 et seq.
   Traffic direction during emergencies - see TRAF.
404.08
   Transportation of radioactive materials - see TRAF.
Ch. 448
   Misconduct at emergencies - see GEN. OFF.
648.06
   Ground surface hazards - see B. & H.
1490.11(e)
1074.01 PURPOSE.
   The purpose of this chapter is to provide for compensation to the Village
for costs incurred in investigating, mitigating, minimizing, removing or
abating unauthorized spills, releases or discharges of materials into or upon
the environment within the territorial jurisdiction or responsibility of the
Village, which spills, releases or discharges require emergency action to
protect the public health, safety or the environment.
(Ord. 1989-97. Passed 10-25-89.)
1074.02 DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter:
   (a)   "Common carrier by motor vehicle" has the same meaning as in Ohio R.C.
4919.75(D) or 4921.02(A), as appropriate.
   (b)   "Contract carrier by motor vehicle" has the same meaning as in Ohio
R.C. 4919.75(E) or 4923.02(A), as appropriate.
   (c)   "Costs" means, but is not limited to, all direct and incidental costs,
including personnel costs, incurred by or on behalf of the Village in
connection with the investigation, mitigation, minimization, removal or
abatement of an unauthorized spill, release or discharge, in the following
respects:
      (1)   Operating any vehicle, apparatus or equipment used in connection
with any such incident;
      (2)   Sanitizing, cleaning and/or repairing any vehicle, apparatus,
equipment or apparel used in connection with any such incident;
      (3)   Testing any spilled, released or discharged material, or any
vehicle, apparatus, equipment or apparel used in connection with any such
incident;
      (4)   Storing any spilled, released or discharged material;
      (5)   Disposing of any spilled, released or discharged material, or any
vehicle, apparatus, equipment, apparel or goods rendered unusable as a result
of any such incident;
      (6)   Replacing any vehicle, apparatus, equipment, apparel or goods lost
or rendered unusable as a result of any such incident; and
      (7)   Any costs incurred by any private party or governmental body, or
subdivision thereof, whose assistance is requested by the Village in the event
of an unauthorized spill, release or discharge, and who submits a written
invoice to the Village setting forth its costs incurred in responding to the
incident.
   (d)   "Material" has the same meaning as in Ohio R.C. 3745.13 and any
regulations promulgated or matters decided thereunder, as appropriate.
   (e)   "Motor vehicle" means any automobile, truck, tractor, trailer,
semitrailer, motorbus or other self-propelled vehicle not operated or driven on
fixed tracks.
   (f)   "Private motor carrier" has the same meaning as in Ohio R.C. 4923.02.
   (g)   "Railroad" has the same meaning as in Ohio R.C. 4907.02.
   (h)   "Unauthorized spill, release or discharge" has the same meaning as in
Ohio R.C. Chapter 3745 and any regulations promulgated or matters decided
thereunder, and shall include, but not be limited to, any spilling, leaking,
pumping, pouring, emitting, emptying, discharging, releasing, injecting,
escaping, leaching, dumping or disposing of any material, into or upon the
environment, which may endanger the public health or safety or the environment.
The term does not include any spill, release or discharge that is in compliance
with Ohio R.C. Chapter 1509, 3704, 3734 or 6111 and the rules adopted
thereunder, or the terms and conditions of a current and valid permit or
license.
(Ord. 1989-97. Passed 10-25-89.)
1074.03 LIABILITY.
   (a)   Any person responsible for causing or allowing an unauthorized spill,
release or discharge of material into or upon the environment is liable to the
Village for disaster services rendered and all incidental and related costs.
The costs shall be paid by the person responsible for causing or allowing the
unauthorized spill, release or discharge of materials into or upon the
environment that requires emergency action to protect the public health or
safety or the environment.
   (b)   If an unauthorized spill, release or discharge occurs from a motor
vehicle or train being operated by, or on behalf of, a common carrier by motor
vehicle, a contract carrier by motor vehicle, a private motor carrier or a
railroad, a claim of civil action shall be submitted to or brought against, as
appropriate, and the costs of the emergency action shall be recovered from, the
motor carrier or railroad, regardless of whether the motor carrier or railroad
was responsible for causing or allowing the unauthorized spill, release or
discharge to occur.
   (c)   Costs recoverable under this chapter shall accrue commencing with the
first notification to the Village of an incident involving, or which may
involve, or subsequently proves to involve, an unauthorized spill, release or
discharge.
(Ord. 1989-97. Passed 10-25-89.)
1074.04 SERVICES OF OTHER GOVERNMENTAL BODIES OR PARTIES.
   (a)   The Fire Chief, or his or her designated officers or fire-fighters,
shall have the authority to request the assistance of any other governmental
body or agency or division thereof in the event of an unauthorized spill,
release or discharge at a location within the territorial jurisdiction or
responsibility of the Village.
   (b)   The Fire Chief, or his or her designated officers or fire-fighters,
shall have the authority to request the assistance of any expert, consultant or
contractor in the event of an unauthorized spill, release or discharge at a
location within the territorial jurisdiction or responsibility of the Village.
(Ord. 1989-97. Passed 10-25-89.)
1074.05 PROCEDURE.
   (a)   The Fire Chief, or his or her designated representative, shall keep a
record of the Village's costs for investigating, mitigating, minimizing,
removing or abating the unauthorized spill, release or discharge, including any
incidental costs. A schedule of charges used to determine such costs shall be
kept on file in the Fire Department and made available for inspection by the
public during normal working hours. The schedule shall be revised, as
necessary, to reflect increases and decreases in the value of the items listed.
   (b)   Not less than thirty days before bringing civil action for the
recovery of costs pursuant to this section and Ohio R.C. 3745.13, the Solicitor
shall submit to the responsible party a written itemized claim for the total
certified costs incurred by the Village and a written notice stating that
unless the amount is paid to the Village within thirty days after the date of
the mailing of the claim and notice, the Solicitor will bring a civil action
for that amount.
(Ord. 1989-97. Passed 10-25-89.)

   CROSS REFERENCES
   Land appropriation for parks - see Ohio R.C. 715.21, 719.01
   Playgrounds, recreation centers, swimming pools - see Ohio R.C. 755.12 et
seq.
   Vacation of parks - see Ohio R.C. 755.41 to 755.43

   Disturbing a lawful meeting - see GEN. OFF.

648.11
1076.01 DESIGNATION OF BACCI PARK AS RECREATIONAL AREA; USAGE.
   The Village property known as "The Louis J. Bacci Recreational Park" (Bacci
Park), situated on Canal Road in the Village, shall be used as a recreational
area in accordance with the provisions of this chapter.
(Ord. 2000-77. Passed 5-10-00.)
1076.02 RULES AND REGULATIONS.
   The following rules and regulations shall apply to the use of Bacci Park,
the swimming pool and adjoining complex, Village Hall, Klima Gardens and
generally to all other Village parks, trails and recreation areas, unless
otherwise specified in the ordinances of the Village, where more rules for a
specific property or properties are set forth in another provision of the
Codified Ordinances, the more stringent of the rules shall apply:
   (a)   Use of the baseball fields shall be by residents, Cuyahoga Heights
School teams, Village baseball programs and Village company teams only and
shall require a permit obtainable according to Section
1076.03.
   (b)   Cuyahoga Heights School teams, Village baseball teams and Village
company teams shall be exempt from fees and deposits at all times.
   (c)   Use of the baseball fields and/or baseball pavilions on the weekends
for private use shall require a deposit and shall be used by residents only
according to Sections
1076.03 and
1076.06.
   (d)   Gas grills or open burning on the grounds are not permitted anywhere
in the park. Existing Village charcoal grills may be used by patrons supplying
their own charcoal. Wood burning is not permitted in the grills. Wood burning
will be permitted only in the fireplace of the Ice Skating Pavilion.
   (e)   No person who is the owner or has charge of any animal shall allow the
animal to run at large without being secured by a leash or shall fail to
remove, in a sanitary manner with proper disposal, any and all feces from the
animal. Any person who violates this division (e) shall be guilty of a
misdemeanor of the fourth degree. A second violation of this division (e)
within one year shall be a misdemeanor of the third degree.
   (f)   Use of any facility in the park is at one's own risk. The Village is
not responsible for any accident or injury which occurs. Emergency phones will
be available for assistance from the Village Police and Fire Departments.
   (g)   No alcoholic beverages are permitted in the park at any time.
   (h)   No parking anywhere on the lawns will be permitted.
   (i)   The park will open at 9:00 a.m. daily and close at dusk, which
includes the use of all parking lots.
   (j)   Conduct that is likely to provoke a violent response; conduct which
presents a risk of physical harm to oneself or another, or to the property of
another; obscene or abusive language; or unreasonable noise, displays, or
gestures are prohibited.
   (k)   No person shall refuse to leave Village property if ordered to do so
by a Village employee.
   (l)   The Director of Parks and Recreation is authorized to draft rules of
conduct on any of the properties subject to this section and is authorized to
enforce those rules and any other rules set forth in the Codified Ordinances.
Further, in addition to the penalties set forth in this chapter, Village
employees are authorized to remove persons or groups who violate any rules set
forth in this chapter or created pursuant to the authority delegated to the
Director of Parks and Recreation from Village property.
(Ord. 2000-77. Passed 5-10-00; Ord. 2005-112. Passed 6-22-05; Ord. 2012-28.
Passed 4-2-12; Ord. 2025-38. Passed 6-11-25.)
1076.03 USE OF BASEBALL FIELDS.
   (a)   Only Village residents, Cuyahoga Heights School teams, Village
baseball programs, Village company teams, and any other authorized baseball
team with the Mayor’s approval shall be permitted to use the baseball fields.
The Cuyahoga Heights Village Baseball program and the Cuyahoga Heights Schools
have priority for use of the baseball fields.
   (b)   Use of the baseball fields at Bacci Park will be by permit only,
obtainable through the Village Hall, with rules set forth by the Mayor's
office. However, Village residents may use the fields for themselves or their
children, until such time as a permit holder appears with a valid permit to use
the baseball fields.
   (c)   A Village resident may obtain a permit for a team practice on a
baseball field if the resident is a player on a team not affiliated with the
Village. The resident must be participating in and be present at the practice.
   (d)   Company teams for companies located in the Village of Cuyahoga Heights
may obtain a permit to practice on the fields.
   (e)   A permit for a baseball field may also reserve the use of the adjacent
baseball pavilion at Bacci Park, if available, subject to the regulations set
forth in Section
1076.06.
   (f)   Use of the baseball fields will require a twenty-five dollar ($25.00)
deposit, which may be waived for the Cuyahoga Heights Village baseball program
and the Cuyahoga Heights Schools. Permits shall be issued on a first come
basis. However, no more than two permits shall not be issued to any applicant
without separate approval of the Mayor to ensure fair opportunity for use of
the baseball fields by other eligible permit seekers.
   (g)   The permit holder must be at the fields with the permit during use and
must present the permit to the Police Department and other Village officials or
representatives upon request.
(Ord. 2000-77. Passed 5-10-00; Ord. 2005-112. Passed 6-22-05; Ord. 2014-72.
Passed 5-19-14.)
1076.04 USE OF POND AND SKATING PAVILION.
   (a)   Ice skating on the pond at Bacci Park is permitted only when the sign
at the pond is posted “OPEN”. The Service Director shall regulate this sign.
   (b)   Ice skating will be at one's own risk. An adult must accompany young
children.
   (c)   Wood burning will be permitted only in the fireplace at the Ice
Skating Pavilion.
   (d)   Swimming is not permitted at any time in the pond.
   (e)   Fishing in the pond will only be allowed in the summer months, during
park hours, and by permit obtained from the Village. Permits shall only be
issued to the Village residents holding a valid State of Ohio Fishing License.
The fee for the Village permit shall be ten dollars ($10.00) and shall be valid
for summer. No ice fishing is permitted. No boats or canoes are permitted.
   (f)   Use of the Ice Skating Pavilion shall be subject to the permit and
other requirements of Section
1076.06 and subject to the regulations of Section
1076.02.
(Ord. 2000-77. Passed 5-10-00; Ord. 2014-72. Passed 5-19-14.)
1076.05 USE OF CLEVELAND METROPARKS.
   The rules and regulations of the Cleveland Metroparks shall govern use of
the Cleveland Metroparks within the Village, including the baseball field and
pavilion on East 49th Street.
(Ord. 2000-77. Passed 5-10-00.)
1076.06 USE OF PAVILIONS AT BACCI PARK.
   (a)   Use of the pavilions at Bacci Park shall be by permit only, obtainable
at the Village Hall. Permits will be issued to Village residents, Village
businesses and Village organizations only, according to rules set forth by the
Mayor's office. Permits shall be issued on a first come basis. However, no more
than two permits shall not be issued to any applicant without separate approval
of the Mayor to ensure fair opportunity for use of the pavilions by other
eligible permit seekers.
   (b)   A permit for the use of a baseball pavilion at Bacci Park may also
reserve the use of the adjacent baseball field, if available, according to the
rules set forth in Section
1076.03.
   (c)   There shall be a nonrefundable deposit of fifty dollars ($50.00)
payable at the time the permit is obtained. If there is any damage to the
property caused by the applicant or their guests, except normal wear and tear,
the renter shall not be eligible to rent any Village facilities for a minimum
period of one year following the event.
   (d)   Use of all pavilions will be subject to the rules listed in Section
1076.02. Tents are not permitted in the Park. Picnics, or other events or
gatherings, shall be limited to fifty persons per pavilion.
   (e)   Excess trash from a private picnic, which exceeds the space in a trash
can, must be bagged and tied and placed next to the trash can.
   (f)   Pavilions must be cleaned and all picnic tables returned to their
original positions in the pavilion.
   (g)   The permit holder must be at the pavilion with the permit during use
and must present the permit upon request to the Police Department and other
Village officials or representatives.
(Ord. 2000-77. Passed 5-10-00; Ord. 2014-72. Passed 5-19-14; Ord. 2022-94.
Passed 12-14-22.)
1076.07 USE OF THE VILLAGE TRAILS.
   (a)   The following restrictions shall apply to all Village hiking or biking
trails.
      (1)   All posted signs or signals must be obeyed, including, but not
limited to restrictions on time of day usage. If use is permitted between
sundown and sunrise, bicycles must have a front headlight and rear reflector to
provide safe passage for the operator and other trail users.
      (2)   Unless otherwise restricted by posted sign, use of trails may
include bicycles, walking, hiking, jogging, skates, roller blades and
skateboards. Stunt maneuvers and operations in a manner unsafe to the operator
or other trail users are prohibited.
      (3)   No motorized vehicles are permitted on the trails, except golf
carts, provided the operator has a valid permit pursuant to Chapter 450 of the
Village Code, motorized wheelchairs and scooters for persons requiring such
devices to be mobile, and motorized vehicles which are permitted to be used on
trails operated by the Cleveland Metroparks that are located in the Village or
adjacent to a Village park or trial. No motorized vehicle shall exceed ten
miles per hour. Emergency, public safety, law enforcement and maintenance
vehicles are exempted from this subsection.
      (4)   Loitering, camping or sleeping along the trails is not permitted.
      (5)   No person shall affect or interfere with an adjacent landowner’s
real property or right to privacy.
      (6)   No person who is the owner or has charge of any animal shall allow
the animal to run at large on the trail without being secured by a leash or
shall fail to remove, in a sanitary manner with proper disposal, any and all
feces from the animal. Any person who violates this subsection (a)(6) shall be
guilty of a misdemeanor of the fourth degree. A second violation of this
subsection (a)(6) within one year shall be a misdemeanor of the third degree.
(Ord. 2012-12. Passed 2-8-12; Ord. 2012-28. Passed 4-2-12; Ord. 2020-52. Passed
7-8-20.)
1076.08 EAST 49TH STREET PARKING LOT.
   (a)   The Village has designated a parking lot on East 49th Street for use
by residents of the Village and their guests. Use of the parking lot is subject
to the following rules and regulations:
      (1)   Only Village residents may secure a permit to use the parking lot.
      (2)   Permits must be obtained from Village Hall during normal business
hours.
      (3)   All vehicles parked in the lot must have valid registrations
through the Ohio Bureau of Motor Vehicles.
      (4)   Hours of operation are Sunday through Thursday from 9:00 a.m. to
11:00 p.m. and Friday and Saturday from 9:00 a.m. to midnight.
      (5)   Vehicles may only park in established parking spaces. Parking on
the grass and/or the sidewalk is strictly prohibited.
      (6)   The parking lot shall be kept clean from debris litter and debris
at all times.
      (7)   Congregating in the parking lot is strictly prohibited.
      (8)   The consumption of alcohol in the parking lot is strictly
prohibited.
   (b)   Failure to comply with any of the rules and regulations herein may
result in the removal and impounding of any vehicle or vehicles (at the expense
of the violator.)
   (c)   If any resident or the guest of a resident who applied for a permit
violates any of these rules and regulations, that resident will lose the right
to obtain future permits and will lose the privilege to park in said parking
lot.
   (d)   Any violation of the application procedure and/or the rules and
regulations for use of the parking lot will also be subject to the penalties
provided in Section
1076.99.
(Ord. 2018-31. Passed 3-14-18.)
1076.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of this
chapter is guilty of a minor misdemeanor and shall be fined not more than one
hundred dollars ($100.00) for each offense. A separate offense shall be deemed
committed each day during or on which a violation or noncompliance occurs or
continues.
(Ord. 2000-77. Passed 5-10-00.)

1220.01 ESTABLISHMENT; MEMBERSHIP.
   A Planning Commission is hereby established for the Village. The Commission
shall consist of the Mayor, ex officio, one member of Council to be appointed
by Council and three citizens of the Village to be appointed by the Mayor in
accordance with the provisions of Ohio R.C. 713.01.
(Ord. 1945-80. Passed 11-28-45.)
1220.02 MEETINGS AND SUBMISSIONS.
   (a)   Meetings of the Planning Commission shall be conducted pursuant to
Section
1242.02.
   (b)   A completed application must be submitted to the Village Engineer no
later that the first day of the month preceding the scheduled meeting to be
included on the agenda.
(Ord. 2006-30. Passed 2-8-06.)

1246.10
1222.01 STREET DEFINED.
   As used in this chapter "street" means any right of way which provides the
public with vehicular and pedestrian access to properties abutting thereon.
(Ord. 1966-28. Passed 6-8-66.)
1222.02 MINIMUM SPECIFICATIONS.
   All streets within the Village shall meet the following minimum
specifications:
   (a)   The street shall be not less than fifty feet in width.
   (b)   The paved portion of the street shall be not less than twenty-four
feet in width from curb to curb.
   (c)   The paved portion of the street shall be improved with nine inches of
reinforced concrete with a six-inch by six-inch integral curb of reinforced
concrete.
    (d)   Concrete sidewalks shall be constructed and shall be four inches
thick and sixty inches wide, except that those portions of sidewalks which are
within the limits of a private residential driveway shall be six inches thick
and reinforced.
    (e)   Aprons for all driveways abutting on the street shall be provided and
shall be made of six inches of reinforced concrete.
   (f)   The standard for the materials and construction of any of the
improvements required herein shall be the specifications of the Ohio Department
of Transportation then in effect, except in those instances where, in the
opinion of the Village Engineer, such standards should be modified to meet
unusual circumstances.
(Ord. 1966-28. Passed 6-8-66.)
   (g)   Storm and sanitary sewers shall be constructed in accordance with the
Rules, Regulations and Standards for the Design and Construction of Sewerage
Improvements as formulated by the Committee on Uniform Standards, dated May 11,
1978, as adopted by the Village in Section
1042.08 of these Codified Ordinances.
(Ord. 1978-67. Passed 10-11-78.)
   (h)   Water mains and all appurtenances thereto shall be provided in
accordance with the standards of, and shall be subject to the approval of, the
Water Division of the City of Cleveland.
   (i)   The unpaved portions of all streets shall be seeded.
   (j)   All utility locations within the street shall be approved by the
Village Engineer and by the companies providing such utilities.
(Ord. 1966-28. Passed 6-8-66.)
1222.03 IMPROVEMENT OR GUARANTEE REQUIRED.
   No plat of a subdivision of land in the Village which involves the opening,
widening or extension of any street shall be approved or accepted, no lot in
any such subdivision shall be sold or leased, and no building permit shall be
issued for the improvement of any lot in any such subdivision, unless all
streets in such subdivision are first improved in accordance with the
specifications set forth in Section
1222.02, or unless the subdivider files with the Village Clerk an agreement and
bond in form satisfactory to the Solicitor and in an amount equal to the
approximate total cost of such improvements, which will insure and guarantee
that all the required improvements shall be completed within one year after
final approval of the plat.
(Ord. 1959-74. Passed 1-13-60.)
1222.04 TRAFFIC CONTROL DURING CONSTRUCTION.
   The Village, when deemed necessary may also require, as a condition of
approval for the opening, widening, repair or extension pursuant to this
chapter, that to further maintain uninterrupted vehicular traffic and to
reasonably and adequately protect pedestrian and vehicular traffic against
accidents, the permittee shall hire one or more law enforcement officers, as
determined by the Mayor, to direct traffic and perform road safety control
services at the hours specified by the Village and at rates set forth by the
Village.
(Ord. 2004-61. Passed 4-14-04; Ord. 2010-59. Passed 6-9-10.)

CHAPTER 1240
General Provisions, Definitions and Penalty
1240.01   Interpretation; application.
1240.02   Amendments.
1240.03   Definitions.
 
1240.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Division of municipal corporation into zones - see Ohio R.C. 713.06
   Notice and hearing on municipal zoning regulations - see Ohio R.C. 713.12
   Effect of zoning on laws and charters - see Ohio R.C. 713.14
   Retroactive zoning ordinances prohibited - see Ohio R.C. 713.15
    1240.01   INTERPRETATION; APPLICATION.
   In interpreting and applying the provisions of this Zoning Code, they shall
be held to be the minimum requirements adopted for the promotion of public
health, safety, comfort, convenience and general welfare. This Zoning Code
shall not repeal, abrogate, annul or in any way impair or interfere with any
existing provisions of law, resolutions or ordinances, or any rules or
regulations previously adopted, or which shall be adopted pursuant to law
relating to the use of buildings or premises, nor shall this Zoning Code
interfere with, abrogate or annul any easement, covenant or other agreement
between parties.
(Ord. 1953-21. Passed 5-13-53.)
1240.02 AMENDMENTS.
   Council may, on its own motion or by petition, after the notice and hearing
required by law, amend the provisions of this Zoning Code, but no such
amendment shall be passed until the same shall have been first submitted to the
Planning Commission for approval, and the Commission shall have been allowed a
reasonable time, not less than thirty days, for consideration and report
thereon.
(Ord. 1953-21. Passed 5-13-53.)
1240.03 DEFINITIONS.
   (a)   As used in this chapter, words used in the present tense include the
future; the singular number includes the plural, and the plural the singular;
the word "lot" includes the word "plot"; the word "building" includes the word
"structure"; the word "occupies" includes the words "designed or intended to be
occupied"; the word "used" includes the words "arranged, designed or intended
to be used"; the word "shall" is mandatory and not directory; and the word
"residence" includes the word "dwelling".
   (b)   In addition, as used in this chapter:
      (1)   "Accessory building" means a subordinate building or portion of a
main building, the use of which is incidental to that of the main building.
      (2)   "Boarding house" means a building, other than a hotel, where
lodging and meals for more than six nontransient persons are served for
compensation.
      (3)   "Building height" means the mean vertical distance from the average
established grade in front of the lot, or from the average natural grade at the
building line, if higher, to the highest point in the coping of flat roofs, or
to the deck line of a mansard roof, or to the mid-height of the highest gable
or dormer of a pitched or hipped roof or, if there are no gables or dormers, to
the mid-height of a pitched or hipped roof.
      (4)   "Building line" means the minimum horizontal distance between the
street lot line and the enclosed parts of the building.
      (5)   "Double house" means a detached dwelling arranged, intended and
designed to be occupied by two families, with a vertical party wall or walls
separating the living quarters of each. Each of the living quarters shall
conform to the requirements for a single dwelling.
      (6)   "Duplex house" means a double house with the front or main entrance
for each family facing on intersecting streets and occupying the lot at the
intersection thereof, with a vertical party wall or walls separating the living
quarters of each. Each of the living quarters shall conform to the requirements
for a single dwelling.
      (7)   "Dwelling" means a building arranged, intended or designed to be
occupied by not more than two families living independently of each other and
doing their own cooking upon the premises.
      (8)   "Family" means any number of individuals living together as a
single housekeeping unit and using certain rooms and housekeeping facilities in
common, as distinguished from a group occupying a boarding house, lodging house
or hotel, as a more or less temporary place of abode.
      (9)   "Garage" means a garage for storage only, for private use, having
no business, commercial service or industry with respect to motor vehicles in
connection therewith.
      (10)   "Half story" means a partial story under a gable, hip or gambrel
roof, the wall plates of which on at least two opposite exterior walls are not
more than four feet above the floor of such story, except that any partial
story used for residence purposes shall be deemed a full story.
      (11)   "Lot" means land occupied by one building or one unit group of
buildings and its accessory buildings and uses, including such open spaces as
are provided or required by this Zoning Code. For any new or added
construction, the lot shall be defined on the plan filed with the Building
Department.
      (12)   "Nonconforming use" means the lawful use of land existing at the
time of the enactment of Ordinance 1953-21, passed May 13, 1953, that does not
conform to the provisions of this Zoning Code for the district in which it is
located.
      (13)   "Single-family dwelling" means a dwelling entirely detached and
independent from any other structure arranged, intended and designed to be
occupied by a single family. It shall contain not less than 960 square feet of
floor area if a one-story house, 800 square feet on the first floor if a one
and one-half story house and a total of not less than 1,400 square feet if a
two-story house, and shall consist of not less than three rooms and a bath. It
shall have, in addition, an approved utility room, a partial basement or a full
basement.
      (14)   "Structure" means anything constructed or erected, the use of
which requires a fixed location on the ground or an attachment to something
having a fixed location on the ground.
      (15)   "Structural alteration" means any change in the stairs or in the
supporting members of a building, such as bearing walls, columns, beams or
girders.
(Ord. 1953-21. Passed 5-13-53.)
      (16)   "Two-family dwelling" means a detached dwelling arranged, intended
and designed to be occupied by two families, one of which has its principal
living rooms upon the first floor and the other of which has its principal
living rooms upon the second floor, and which contains not less than 1,000
square feet of floor area, not less than four living rooms and a bath for each
family unit.
(Ord. 1960-57. Passed 1-11-61.)
      (17)   "Yard" means an open space on the same lot with a building,
unoccupied and unobstructed from the ground upward, except as otherwise
provided in this Zoning Code.
         A.   "Front yard" means a space within and extending the full width of
the lot between the street lot line and the enclosed parts of the building
setting back from the nearest such street lot line.
         B.   "Rear yard" means a space within and extending the full width of
the lot between the rear walls of the building and the rear lot line of the
lot.
         C.   "Side yard" means a space within the lot between a side lot line
and the side walls of the building nearest thereto. Side yards shall extend
through from the street line or the front yard to the rear yard. The least
width of any side yard space shall be measured at right angles to the side lot
line. When an unbroken section of a side wall is not parallel with the side lot
line, the required width of any side yard space shall be taken as the average
width, provided that the side yard space shall not be narrower than three feet
at any point.
      (18)   "Zoning Code" means Ordinance 1953-21, passed May 13, 1953, as
amended, codified as Title Four of Part Twelve - the Planning and Zoning Code.
(Ord. 1953-21. Passed 5-13-53.)
1240.99 PENALTY.
   The owner of any building or premises, or part thereof, where anything in
violation of this Zoning Code shall be placed or shall exist, and any
architect, builder or contractor who may be employed to assist in the
commission of any such violation, and any person who violates any of the
provisions of this Zoning Code or fails to comply with any of the requirements
thereof, or who shall build in violation of any detailed statement of plans
submitted and approved hereunder, is guilty of a misdemeanor of the fourth
degree and shall be fined not more than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) or
imprisoned not more than thirty days, or both, for each offense. A separate
offense shall be deemed committed each day during or on which a violation or
noncompliance occurs or continues.
(Ord. 1979-17. Passed 2-14-79.)
CHAPTER 1242
Board of Zoning Appeals
1242.01   Establishment; members.
1242.02   Meetings.
1242.03   Secretary; records; report.
1242.04   Appeals.
1242.05   Notice and hearing required; quorum.
1242.06   Methods of notice.

1242.08   Action by Council; special permit.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Administrative board; powers and duties - see Ohio R.C. 713.11
   Limitation on procedural challenges - see Ohio R.C. 713.121
   Violation of zoning ordinances may be enjoined - see Ohio R.C. 713.13
   Appeals to Board under Building Code - see B. & H.
1446.01 et seq.
   Issuance of permits for topsoil, sand or gravel removal - see B. & H.
1484.02
1242.01 ESTABLISHMENT; MEMBERS.
   A Board of Zoning Appeals is hereby established, consisting of the Mayor and
all members of the Planning Commission. The term of office of each member of
the Board shall be co-extensive with his or her term as Mayor or as a member of
the Planning Commission. Attendance shall be in person.
(Ord. 1953-21. Passed 5-13-53.)
1242.02 MEETINGS.
   (a)   Meetings of the Board shall be held in the Village Hall on the third
Wednesday of each month. Additional meetings may also be held upon the call of
the Mayor, who shall serve as Chairperson of the Board, or upon the call of any
two members of the Board.
   (b)   Non-elected officials who are members of the Board shall be
compensated seventy-five dollars ($75.00) for each Board meeting attended.
(Ord. 1953-21. Passed 5-13-53; Ord. 2006-28. Passed 2-8-06.)
1242.03 SECRETARY; RECORDS; REPORT.
   The Village Clerk shall be the Secretary of the Board. The Secretary shall
keep a permanent record of the attendance and the proceedings of the Board
showing its action and vote on each case. At the end of each calendar year, the
Secretary shall make an annual report of the work of the Board.
(Ord. 1953-21. Passed 5-13-53.)
1242.04 APPEALS.
   Any determination by the Building Commissioner made in the enforcement of
this Zoning Code may be appealed to the Board by any person deeming himself or
herself adversely affected by such decision. The appeal shall be initiated by
filing with the Secretary of the Board an application in writing, setting forth
the determination appealed from, the pertinent facts and the relief desired.
(Ord. 1953-21. Passed 5-13-53.)
1242.05 NOTICE AND HEARING REQUIRED; QUORUM.
   No action of the Board shall be taken on any case until after proper notice
has been given and a public hearing has been held. The presence of three
members shall constitute a quorum and the concurring vote of three members of
the Board shall be necessary to reverse or modify any order, requirement,
decision or determination of the Building Commissioner, or to decide in favor
of the appellant any matter upon which the Board is required to pass or to
effect any variations.
(Ord. 1953-21. Passed 5-13-53.)
1242.06 METHODS OF NOTICE.
   Written notice of the scheduled hearing shall be mailed to the owner or his
or her agent at the address given on the appeal and, as far as practicable,
written notice to affected property owners or their agents, at least five days
prior to the date of the proposed hearing. Failure to notify affected property
owners shall not prevent the Board from conducting a hearing and acting
thereafter.
(Ord. 1953-21. Passed 5-13-53; Ord. 2006-29. Passed 2-8-06.)
1242.07 POWERS OF BOARD; VARIANCES AND DECISIONS ON APPEALS.
   Where there are practical difficulties or unnecessary hardships in the way
of carrying out the strict letter of the provisions of this Zoning Code, the
Board shall have the power in a specific case to vary the application of any
such provision in harmony with the general purpose and intent of this Zoning
Code so that the public health, safety, morals and general welfare may be
secured and substantial justice done.
   The Board may reverse or affirm, wholly or in part, or may modify, the
order, requirement, decision or determination appealed from, and shall make the
order, requirement, decision or determination as in its opinion ought to be
made under the circumstances. To that end, the Board shall have the powers of
the officer from whom the appeal is taken and may issue or direct the issuance
of a permit.
(Ord. 1953-21. Passed 5-13-53.)
1242.08 ACTION BY COUNCIL; SPECIAL PERMIT.
   The Secretary of the Board shall immediately notify the Building
Commissioner and Council of any action taken by the Board on an appeal. Council
may, at its next ensuing meeting, affirm, modify or reverse the decision of the
Board. If no action is taken by Council at its next ensuing meeting, the
decision of the Board shall be final. When a special permit has been granted by
the Board or by Council, the Clerk shall forward a written notice thereof to
the Building Commissioner, who shall incorporate the special conditions, if
any, on the permit when issued.
(Ord. 1954-75. Passed 10-27-54.)

CHAPTER 1246
Residence Districts
1246.01   Uses permitted.
1246.02   Accessory buildings permitted.

   CROSS REFERENCES
   Division of municipal corporation into zones - see Ohio R.C. 713.06
   Restrictions on location, bulk and height of buildings and structures - see
Ohio R.C. 713.07
   Restrictions on height of buildings and structures - see Ohio R.C. 713.08
   Restrictions on percentage of lot occupancy and set-back building lines -
see Ohio R.C. 713.09
   Basis of districting or zoning; classification of buildings or structures -
